**Yerevan** ( [UK](/wiki/British_English "British English"): [/ˌjɛrəˈvæn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*YERR-ə-VAN*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"), [US](/wiki/American_English "American English"): [/-ˈvɑːn/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"), [*-⁠VAHN*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"); [Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language"): Երևան^[\[c\]](#cite_note-28)^ [\[jɛɾɛˈvɑn\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Armenian "Help:IPA/Armenian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/f/f4/Audio_Yerewan.ogg/Audio_Yerewan.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Audio_Yerewan.ogg "File:Audio Yerewan.ogg")^; sometimes spelled **Erevan** )^[\[d\]](#cite_note-31)^ is the capital and largest city of [Armenia](/wiki/Armenia "Armenia"), as well as one of the world's [oldest continuously inhabited cities](/wiki/List_of_oldest_continuously_inhabited_cities "List of oldest continuously inhabited cities").^[\[28\]](#cite_note-32)^ Situated along the [Hrazdan River](/wiki/Hrazdan_River "Hrazdan River"), Yerevan is the administrative, cultural, and industrial center of the country, as its [primate city](/wiki/Primate_city "Primate city"). It has been the [capital](/wiki/Historical_capitals_of_Armenia "Historical capitals of Armenia") since 1918, the [fourteenth in the history of Armenia](/wiki/Historical_capitals_of_Armenia "Historical capitals of Armenia") and the seventh located in or around the [Ararat Plain](/wiki/Ararat_Plain "Ararat Plain"). The city also serves as the seat of the [Araratian Pontifical Diocese](/wiki/Araratian_Pontifical_Diocese "Araratian Pontifical Diocese"), which is the largest diocese of the [Armenian Apostolic Church](/wiki/Armenian_Apostolic_Church "Armenian Apostolic Church") and one of the oldest dioceses in the world.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-araratian-tem1-33)^{#cite_ref-araratian-tem1_33-0}

The history of Yerevan dates back to the 8th century BC, with the founding of the fortress of [Erebuni](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress") in 782 BC by King [Argishti I](/wiki/Argishti_I_of_Urartu "Argishti I of Urartu") of [Urartu](/wiki/Urartu "Urartu") at the western extreme of the Ararat Plain.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-34)^ Erebuni was "designed as a great administrative and religious centre, a fully royal capital."^[\[31\]](#cite_note-Barnett-35)^ By the late [ancient Armenian Kingdom](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Armenia_(antiquity) "Kingdom of Armenia (antiquity)"), new capital cities were established and Yerevan declined in importance. The city was mostly depopulated by the [Great Surgun](/wiki/Great_Surgun "Great Surgun") of 1603--05, when the [Safavid Empire](/wiki/Safavid_Iran "Safavid Iran") forcibly deported hundreds of thousands of Armenians to Iran. In 1679, the city was mostly destroyed by an [earthquake](/wiki/1679_Armenia_earthquake "1679 Armenia earthquake"), and then rebuilt on a smaller scale. In 1828, Yerevan became part of the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"), which led to the repatriation of Armenians whose ancestors had been forcibly relocated in the 17th century. After [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), Yerevan became the capital of the [First Republic of Armenia](/wiki/First_Republic_of_Armenia "First Republic of Armenia") as thousands of [survivors](/wiki/Armenian_genocide_survivors "Armenian genocide survivors") of the [Armenian genocide](/wiki/Armenian_genocide "Armenian genocide") in the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") arrived in the area.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-36)^ The city expanded rapidly during the 20th century while [Armenia](/wiki/Armenian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic") was a part of the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"). In a few decades, Yerevan was transformed from a provincial town within the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") to Armenia's principal cultural, artistic, and industrial center, as well as becoming the seat of national government.{#cite_ref-36}

With the growth of the [Armenian economy](/wiki/Economy_of_Armenia "Economy of Armenia"), Yerevan has undergone major transformation. Much construction has been done throughout the city since the early 2000s, and retail outlets such as restaurants, shops, and street cafés, which were rare during Soviet times, have multiplied. As of 2011^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Yerevan&action=edit)^, the population of Yerevan was 1,060,138, just over 35% of Armenia's total population. By 2022, the population further increased to 1,086,677.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-2022_Census-19)^ Yerevan was named the 2012 [World Book Capital](/wiki/World_Book_Capital "World Book Capital") by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO").^[\[33\]](#cite_note-UN_News_Centre-37)^ Yerevan is an associate member of [Eurocities](/wiki/Eurocities "Eurocities").^[\[34\]](#cite_note-38)^{#cite_ref-38}

Of the notable landmarks of Yerevan, [Erebuni Fortress](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress") is considered to be the birthplace of the city, the [Katoghike Tsiranavor](/wiki/Katoghike_Tsiranavor_Church_of_Avan "Katoghike Tsiranavor Church of Avan") church is the oldest surviving church of Yerevan, and [Saint Gregory Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Gregory_the_Illuminator_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Gregory the Illuminator Cathedral, Yerevan") is the largest Armenian cathedral in the world. [Tsitsernakaberd](/wiki/Tsitsernakaberd "Tsitsernakaberd") is the official memorial to the victims of the Armenian genocide. The city is home to several opera houses, theatres, museums, libraries, and other cultural institutions. [Yerevan Opera Theatre](/wiki/Yerevan_Opera_Theatre "Yerevan Opera Theatre") is the main spectacle hall of the Armenian capital, the [National Gallery of Armenia](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Armenia "National Gallery of Armenia") is the largest art museum in Armenia and shares a building with the [History Museum of Armenia](/wiki/History_Museum_of_Armenia "History Museum of Armenia"), and the [Matenadaran](/wiki/Matenadaran "Matenadaran") contains one of the largest depositories of ancient books and manuscripts in the world.  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Erevan_-_La_forterese_d%27Erebouni_07.JPG/220px-Erevan_-_La_forterese_d%27Erebouni_07.JPG)](/wiki/File:Erevan_-_La_forterese_d%27Erebouni_07.JPG) The "birth certificate" of Yerevan at the [Erebuni Fortress](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress")---a [cuneiform](/wiki/Cuneiform "Cuneiform") inscription left by King [Argishti I of Urartu](/wiki/Argishti_I_of_Urartu "Argishti I of Urartu") on a basalt stone slab about the foundation of the city in 782 BCE [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Tsaghkadzor%2C_Kecharis%2C_S._Nshan%2C_timpano_%28Yerevan_in_inscription%29.jpg/220px-Tsaghkadzor%2C_Kecharis%2C_S._Nshan%2C_timpano_%28Yerevan_in_inscription%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tsaghkadzor,_Kecharis,_S._Nshan,_timpano_(Yerevan_in_inscription).jpg) "YEREVAN" (ԵՐԵՒԱՆ) in an inscription from [Kecharis](/wiki/Kecharis_Monastery "Kecharis Monastery"), dating back to 1223^[\[35\]](#cite_note-39)^  
See also: [Names of Yerevan in different languages](/wiki/Names_of_European_cities_in_different_languages_(U%E2%80%93Z)#Y "Names of European cities in different languages (U–Z)")

The exact origin of the name is unknown. One theory regarding the origin of Yerevan's name is the city was named after the Armenian king, [Yervand (Orontes) IV](/wiki/Orontes_IV "Orontes IV"), the last ruler of Armenia from the [Orontid dynasty](/wiki/Orontid_dynasty "Orontid dynasty"), and founder of the city of [Yervandashat](/wiki/Yervandashat_(ancient_city) "Yervandashat (ancient city)").^[\[36\]](#cite_note-SAE-40)^ However, it is likely that the city's name is derived from the [Urartian](/wiki/Urartian "Urartian") military fortress of [Erebuni](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress"), which was founded on the territory of modern-day Yerevan in 782 BC by [Argishti I](/wiki/Argishti_I_of_Urartu "Argishti I of Urartu").^[\[36\]](#cite_note-SAE-40)^ "Erebuni" may derive from the Urartian word for "to take" or "to capture," meaning that the fortress's name could be interpreted as "capture," "conquest," or "victory."^[\[37\]](#cite_note-41)^ As elements of the [Urartian language](/wiki/Urartian_language "Urartian language") blended with that of the Armenian one, the name eventually evolved into *Yerevan* (Erebuni = Erevani = Erevan = Yerevan). Scholar Margarit Israelyan notes these changes when comparing inscriptions found on two [cuneiform](/wiki/Cuneiform "Cuneiform") tablets at Erebuni:
{#cite_ref-41}
> The transcription of the second cuneiform *bu* \[original emphasis\] of the word was very essential in our interpretation as it is the Urartaean *b* that has been shifted to the [Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language") *v* (b \> v). The original writing of the inscription read \<\<er-bu-ni\>\>; therefore the prominent Armenianologist-[orientalist](/wiki/Oriental_studies "Oriental studies") Prof. G. A. Ghapantsian justly objected, remarking that the Urartu *b* changed to *v* at the beginning of the word (Biani \> Van) or between two vowels (ebani \> avan, Zabaha \> [Javakhk](/wiki/Javakhk "Javakhk"))....In other words *b* was placed between two vowels. The true pronunciation of the fortress-city was apparently *Erebuny* .^[\[38\]](#cite_note-42)^{#cite_ref-42}

Early Christian Armenian chroniclers connected the origin of the city's name to the legend of [Noah's Ark](/wiki/Noah%27s_Ark "Noah's Ark"). After the ark had landed on [Mount Ararat](/wiki/Mount_Ararat "Mount Ararat") and the flood waters had receded, [Noah](/wiki/Noah "Noah"), while looking in the direction of Yerevan, is said to have exclaimed "Yerevats!" ("it appeared!" in [Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language")), from which originated the name Yerevan.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-SAE-40)^{#cite_ref-SAE_40-2}

In the late medieval and early modern periods, when Yerevan was under Turkic and later Persian rule, the city was known in Persian as *Iravân* ([Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language"): ایروان).^[\[39\]](#cite_note-43)^^[\[40\]](#cite_note-44)^ The city was officially known as Erivan ([Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): Эривань) under Russian rule during the 19th and early 20th centuries. The city was renamed back to Yerevan (Ереван) in 1936.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-45)^ Up until the mid-1970s the city's name was spelled Erevan more often than Yerevan in English sources.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-46)^^[\[43\]](#cite_note-47)^{#cite_ref-47}  

Symbols {#Symbols}
------------------

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Mount_Ararat_and_the_Yerevan_skyline.jpg/220px-Mount_Ararat_and_the_Yerevan_skyline.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mount_Ararat_and_the_Yerevan_skyline.jpg) [Mount Ararat](/wiki/Mount_Ararat "Mount Ararat"), the national symbol of Armenia, dominates the Yerevan skyline.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-Worldwide_Destinations-48)^^[\[45\]](#cite_note-49)^

The principal symbol of Yerevan is Mount Ararat, which is visible from any area in the capital. The [seal](/wiki/Seal_(device) "Seal (device)") of the city is a crowned lion on a pedestal with a shield that has a depiction of Mount Ararat on the upper part and half of an [Armenian eternity sign](/wiki/Armenian_eternity_sign "Armenian eternity sign") on the bottom part. The emblem is a rectangular [shield](/wiki/Shield "Shield") with a blue border.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-50)^{#cite_ref-50}

On 27 September 2004, Yerevan adopted an anthem, "Erebuni-Yerevan", using lyrics written by [Paruyr Sevak](/wiki/Paruyr_Sevak "Paruyr Sevak") and set to music composed by [Edgar Hovhannisyan](/wiki/Edgar_Hovhannisyan "Edgar Hovhannisyan"). It was selected in a competition for a new anthem and new flag that would best represent the city. The chosen flag has a white background with the city's seal in the middle, surrounded by twelve small red triangles that symbolize the twelve historic capitals of Armenia. The flag includes the three colours of the [Armenian National flag](/wiki/Flag_of_Armenia "Flag of Armenia"). The lion is portrayed on the orange background with blue edging.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}  

History {#History}
------------------

Main article: [History of Yerevan](/wiki/History_of_Yerevan "History of Yerevan")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Yerevan](/wiki/Timeline_of_Yerevan "Timeline of Yerevan").  

### Pre-history and pre-classical era {#Pre-history_and_pre-classical_era}

See also: [Kura--Araxes culture](/wiki/Kura%E2%80%93Araxes_culture "Kura–Araxes culture")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Shengavit_Settlement_2.jpg/220px-Shengavit_Settlement_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shengavit_Settlement_2.jpg) Foundations of [Shengavit historical site](/wiki/Shengavit_Settlement "Shengavit Settlement") (site settled 3200 BC cal to 2500 BC cal)

The territory of Yerevan has been inhabited since approximately the 2nd half of the [4th millennium BC](/wiki/4th_millennium_BC "4th millennium BC"). The southern part of the city currently known as [Shengavit](/wiki/Shengavit_District "Shengavit District") has been populated since at least 3200 BC, during the period of [Kura--Araxes culture](/wiki/Kura%E2%80%93Araxes_culture "Kura–Araxes culture") of the early [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age"). The first excavations at the [Shengavit historical site](/wiki/Shengavit_Settlement "Shengavit Settlement") was conducted between 1936 and 1938 under the guidance of archaeologist Yevgeny Bayburdyan. After two decades, archaeologist Sandro Sardarian resumed the excavations starting from 1958 until 1983.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-52)^ The 3rd phase of the excavations started in 2000, under the guidance of archaeologist Hakob Simonyan. In 2009, Simonyan was joined by Mitchell S. Rothman from the [Widener University](/wiki/Widener_University "Widener University") of [Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"). Together they conducted three series of excavations in 2009, 2010, and 2012 respectively.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ During the process, a full stratigraphic column to bedrock was reached, showing there to be 8 or 9 distinct stratigraphic levels. These levels cover a time between 3200 BC and 2500 BC. Evidences of later use of the site, possibly until 2200 BC, were also found. The excavation process revealed a series of large round buildings with square adjoining rooms and minor round buildings. A series of ritual installations was discovered in 2010 and 2012.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-52}  

### Erebuni {#Erebuni}

Main article: [Erebuni Fortress](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Yerevan_-_Armeni%C3%AB_%282901349237%29.jpg/220px-Yerevan_-_Armeni%C3%AB_%282901349237%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_-_Armeni%C3%AB_(2901349237).jpg) Painting showing the founding of Yerevan by [Argishti I](/wiki/Argishti_I_of_Urartu "Argishti I of Urartu") in 782 BC ([Erebuni Museum](/wiki/Erebuni_Museum "Erebuni Museum")) [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Erebuni_Fortress%2C_Yerevan%2C_Armenia_01.jpg/220px-Erebuni_Fortress%2C_Yerevan%2C_Armenia_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Erebuni_Fortress,_Yerevan,_Armenia_01.jpg) [Erebuni Fortress](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress"), founded by King [Argishti I](/wiki/Argishti_I_of_Urartu "Argishti I of Urartu") in 782 BC

The ancient kingdom of [Urartu](/wiki/Urartu "Urartu") was formed in the 9th century BC by King [Arame](/wiki/Arame_of_Urartu "Arame of Urartu") in the basin of [Lake Van](/wiki/Lake_Van "Lake Van") of the [Armenian Highland](/wiki/Armenian_Highland "Armenian Highland"), including the territory of modern-day Yerevan.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-53)^ Archaeological evidence, such as a [cuneiform](/wiki/Cuneiform "Cuneiform") inscription,^[\[50\]](#cite_note-54)^ indicates that the [Urartian](/wiki/Urartian "Urartian") military fortress of Erebuni was founded in 782 BC by the orders of King [Argishti I](/wiki/Argishti_I_of_Urartu "Argishti I of Urartu") at the site of modern-day Yerevan, to serve as a fort and citadel guarding against attacks from the north [Caucasus](/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus").^[\[36\]](#cite_note-SAE-40)^ The cuneiform inscription found at Erebuni Fortress reads:{#cite_ref-SAE_40-3}
> By the greatness of the God [Khaldi](/wiki/Khaldi_(god) "Khaldi (god)"), Argishti, son of [Menua](/wiki/Menuas_of_Urartu "Menuas of Urartu"), built this mighty stronghold and proclaimed it Erebuni for the glory of Biainili \[Urartu\] and to instill fear among the king's enemies. Argishti says, "The land was a desert, before the great works I accomplished upon it. By the greatness of Khaldi, Argishti, son of Menua, is a mighty king, king of Biainili, and ruler of Tushpa."\[[Van](/wiki/Van,_Turkey "Van, Turkey")\].^[\[51\]](#cite_note-55)^{#cite_ref-55}

During the height of the Urartian power, [irrigation](/wiki/Irrigation "Irrigation") canals and artificial reservoirs were built in Erebuni and its surrounding territories.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Karmir_Blur_Town.JPG/220px-Karmir_Blur_Town.JPG)](/wiki/File:Karmir_Blur_Town.JPG) Foundations of [Teishebaini](/wiki/Teishebaini "Teishebaini") building commenced in mid-7th century BC

In the mid-7th century BC, the city of [Teishebaini](/wiki/Teishebaini "Teishebaini") was built by [Rusa II](/wiki/Rusa_II "Rusa II") of Urartu, around 7 kilometres (4.3 miles) west of Erebuni Fortress.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-56)^ It was fortified on a hill -currently known as Karmir Blur within [Shengavit District](/wiki/Shengavit_District "Shengavit District") of Yerevan- to protect the eastern borders of Urartu from the barbaric [Cimmerians](/wiki/Cimmerians "Cimmerians") and [Scythians](/wiki/Scythians "Scythians"). During excavations, the remains of a governors palace that contained a hundred and twenty rooms spreading across more than 40,000 m^2^ (10 acres) was found, along with a [citadel](/wiki/Citadel "Citadel") dedicated to the Urartian god [Teisheba](/wiki/Theispas "Theispas"). The construction of the city of Teishebaini, as well as the palace and the citadel was completed by the end of the 7th century BC, during the reign of [Rusa III](/wiki/Rusa_III "Rusa III"). However, Teishebaini was destroyed by an alliance of [Medes](/wiki/Medes "Medes") and the [Scythians](/wiki/Scythians "Scythians") in 585 BC.{#cite_ref-56}  

### Median and Achaemenid rules {#Median_and_Achaemenid_rules}

See also: [Satrapy of Armenia](/wiki/Satrapy_of_Armenia "Satrapy of Armenia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/AchaemenidGoblet01.jpg/170px-AchaemenidGoblet01.jpg)](/wiki/File:AchaemenidGoblet01.jpg) Achaemenid [rhyton](/wiki/Rhyton "Rhyton") from Erebuni

In 590 BC, following the fall of the Kingdom of Urartu at the hands of the Iranian [Medes](/wiki/Medes "Medes"), Erebuni along with the Armenian Highlands became part of the Median Empire.

However, in 550 BC, the [Median Empire](/wiki/Medes "Medes") was conquered by [Cyrus the Great](/wiki/Cyrus_the_Great "Cyrus the Great"), and Erebuni became part of the [Achaemenid Empire](/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire "Achaemenid Empire").^[\[53\]](#cite_note-57)^ Between 522 BC and 331 BC, Erebuni was one of the main centers of the [Satrapy of Armenia](/wiki/Satrapy_of_Armenia "Satrapy of Armenia"), a region controlled by the [Orontid dynasty](/wiki/Orontid_dynasty "Orontid dynasty") as one of the [satrapies](/wiki/Satrapy "Satrapy") of the Achaemenid Empire. The Satrapy of Armenia was divided into two parts: the northern part and the southern part, with the cities of Erebuni (Yerevan) and Tushpa (Van) as their centres, respectively.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}

Coins issued in 478 BC, along with many other items found in the [Erebuni Fortress](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress"), reveal the importance of Erebuni as a major centre for trade under Achaemenid rule.  

### Ancient Kingdom of Armenia {#Ancient_Kingdom_of_Armenia}

See also: [Kingdom of Armenia (antiquity)](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Armenia_(antiquity) "Kingdom of Armenia (antiquity)")

|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) | This section **does not [cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")** . Please help [improve this section](/wiki/Special:EditPage/Yerevan "Special:EditPage/Yerevan") by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). *(February 2023)**([Learn how and when to remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))* |

After [Alexander the Great](/wiki/Alexander_the_Great "Alexander the Great")'s victory over the Achaemenid Empire, the Orontid rulers of the Armenian satrapy achieved independence as a result of the Battle of Gaugamela in 331 BC, founding the [Kingdom of Armenia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Armenia_(antiquity) "Kingdom of Armenia (antiquity)"). With the establishment of new cities such as [Armavir](/wiki/Armavir_(ancient_city) "Armavir (ancient city)"), Zarehavan, [Bagaran](/wiki/Bagaran_(ancient_city) "Bagaran (ancient city)") and [Yervandashat](/wiki/Yervandashat_(ancient_city) "Yervandashat (ancient city)"), the importance of Erebuni gradually declined.

With the rise of the [Artaxiad dynasty](/wiki/Artaxiad_dynasty "Artaxiad dynasty") of Armenia who seized power in 189 BC, the Kingdom of Armenia greatly expanded to include major territories of [Asia Minor](/wiki/Asia_Minor "Asia Minor"), [Atropatene](/wiki/Atropatene "Atropatene"), [Iberia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Iberia_(antiquity) "Kingdom of Iberia (antiquity)"), [Phoenicia](/wiki/Phoenicia "Phoenicia") and [Syria](/wiki/Syria_(region) "Syria (region)"). The Artaxiads considered Erebuni and Tushpa as cities of Persian heritage. Consequently, new cities and commercial centres were built by Kings [Artaxias I](/wiki/Artaxias_I "Artaxias I"), [Artavasdes I](/wiki/Artavasdes_I_of_Armenia "Artavasdes I of Armenia") and [Tigranes the Great](/wiki/Tigranes_the_Great "Tigranes the Great"). Thus, with the dominance of cities such as [Artaxata](/wiki/Artaxata "Artaxata") and [Tigranocerta](/wiki/Tigranocerta "Tigranocerta"), Erebuni significantly lost its importance as a central city.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Sb_Astvatsatsin_Chapel%2C_Avan%2C_Yerevan1.JPG/220px-Sb_Astvatsatsin_Chapel%2C_Avan%2C_Yerevan1.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sb_Astvatsatsin_Chapel,_Avan,_Yerevan1.JPG) The ruins of the 4th-century Holy Mother of God Chapel in Avan, north of Yerevan

Under the rule of the [Arsacid dynasty of Armenia](/wiki/Arsacid_dynasty_of_Armenia "Arsacid dynasty of Armenia") (54--428 AD), many other cities around Erebuni including [Vagharshapat](/wiki/Vagharshapat "Vagharshapat") and [Dvin](/wiki/Dvin_(ancient_city) "Dvin (ancient city)") flourished. Consequently, Erebuni was completely neutralized, losing its role as an economic and strategic centre of Armenia. During the period of the Arsacid kings, Erebuni was only recorded in a [Manichaean](/wiki/Manichaeism "Manichaeism") text of the 3rd century, where it is mentioned that one of the disciples of the prophet [Mani](/wiki/Mani_(prophet) "Mani (prophet)") founded a [Manichaean](/wiki/Manichaeism "Manichaeism") community near the Christian community in Erebuni.

According to the medieval Armenian geography *[Ashkharhatsuyts](/wiki/Ashkharhatsuyts "Ashkharhatsuyts")* , Erebuni was part of the canton (*gawaṙ*) of Kotayk (not to be confused with the current Kotayk Province) of the province of [Ayrarat](/wiki/Ayrarat "Ayrarat"), within Armenia Major.

Armenia became a Christian nation in the early 4th century AD, during the reign of the Arsacid king [Tiridates III](/wiki/Tiridates_III_of_Armenia "Tiridates III of Armenia").  

### Sasanian and Roman periods {#Sasanian_and_Roman_periods}

See also: [Persian Armenia](/wiki/Persian_Armenia "Persian Armenia") and [Marzpanate Armenia](/wiki/Marzpanate_Armenia "Marzpanate Armenia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Avan_1.JPG/220px-Avan_1.JPG)](/wiki/File:Avan_1.JPG) [Katoghike Tsiranavor Church of Avan](/wiki/Katoghike_Tsiranavor_Church_of_Avan "Katoghike Tsiranavor Church of Avan"), 6th century

Following the partition of Armenia by the [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") and [Sasanian](/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire") empires in 387 and in 428, Erebuni and the entire territory of Eastern Armenia came under the rule of Sasanian Persia.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-59)^ The Armenian territories formed the province of [Persian Armenia](/wiki/Persian_Armenia "Persian Armenia") within the [Sasanian Empire](/wiki/Sasanian_Empire "Sasanian Empire").{#cite_ref-59}

Due to the diminished role of Erebuni, as well as the absence of proper historical data, much of the city's history under the Sasanian rule is unknown.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

In 587, during the reign of [emperor Maurice](/wiki/Maurice_(emperor) "Maurice (emperor)"), Yerevan and much of Armenia came under Roman administration after the Romans defeated the [Sassanid Persian Empire](/wiki/Sassanid_Empire "Sassanid Empire") at the [battle of the Blarathon](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Blarathon "Battle of the Blarathon").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Soon after, [Katoghike Tsiranavor Church](/wiki/Katoghike_Tsiranavor_Church_of_Avan "Katoghike Tsiranavor Church of Avan") in [Avan](/wiki/Avan_district "Avan district") was built between 595 and 602. Despite being partly damaged during the [1679 earthquake](/wiki/1679_Armenia_earthquake "1679 Armenia earthquake")), it is the oldest surviving church within modern Yerevan city limits.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

The province of Persian Armenia (also known as Persarmenia) lasted until 646, when the province was dissolved with the [Muslim conquest of Persia](/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia "Muslim conquest of Persia").  

### Arab Islamic invasion {#Arab_Islamic_invasion}

See also: [Arminiya](/wiki/Arminiya "Arminiya")

Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). *(February 2023)**([Learn how and when to remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))* |

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Katokhike_before.png/220px-Katokhike_before.png)](/wiki/File:Katokhike_before.png) The 7th-century church of the Holy Mother of God, demolished in 1936

In 658 AD, at the height of the Arab Islamic invasions, Erebuni-Yerevan was conquered during the [Muslim conquest of Persia](/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_Persia "Muslim conquest of Persia"), as it was part of Persian-ruled Armenia. The city became part of the [Emirate of Armenia](/wiki/Arminiya "Arminiya") under the [Umayyad Caliphate](/wiki/Umayyad_Caliphate "Umayyad Caliphate"). The city of Dvin was the centre of the newly created emirate. Starting from this period, as a result of the developing trade activities with the Arabs, the Armenian territories had gained strategic importance as a crossroads for the Arab [caravan](/wiki/Camel_train "Camel train") routes passing between Europe and India through the Arab-controlled Ararat Plain of Armenia. Most probably, "Erebuni" has become known as "Yerevan" since at least the 7th century AD.  

### Bagratid Armenia {#Bagratid_Armenia}

See also: [Bagratid Armenia](/wiki/Bagratid_Armenia "Bagratid Armenia")

|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) | This section **does not [cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")** . Please help [improve this section](/wiki/Special:EditPage/Yerevan "Special:EditPage/Yerevan") by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). *(May 2023)**([Learn how and when to remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))* |

After two centuries of Islamic rule over Armenia, the [Bagratid](/wiki/Bagratuni_dynasty "Bagratuni dynasty") prince [Ashot I of Armenia](/wiki/Ashot_I_of_Armenia "Ashot I of Armenia") led the revolution against the [Abbasid Caliphate](/wiki/Abbasid_Caliphate "Abbasid Caliphate"). Ashot I liberated Yerevan in 850, and was recognized as the Prince of Princes of Armenia by the Abbasid Caliph [al-Musta'in](/wiki/Al-Musta%27in "Al-Musta'in") in 862. Ashot was later crowned King of [Armenia](/wiki/Bagratid_Armenia "Bagratid Armenia") through the consent of Caliph [al-Mu'tamid](/wiki/Al-Mu%27tamid "Al-Mu'tamid") in 885. During the rule of the Bagratuni dynasty of Armenia between 885 and 1045, Yerevan was relatively a secure part of the Kingdom before falling to the [Byzantines](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire").

However, Yerevan did not have any strategic role during the reign of the Bagratids, who developed many other cities of [Ayrarat](/wiki/Ayrarat "Ayrarat"), such as [Shirakavan](/wiki/Shirakavan_(ancient_city) "Shirakavan (ancient city)"), [Dvin](/wiki/Dvin_(ancient_city) "Dvin (ancient city)"), and [Ani](/wiki/Ani "Ani").  

### Seljuk period, Zakarid Armenia and Mongol rule {#Seljuk_period.2C_Zakarid_Armenia_and_Mongol_rule}

See also: [Zakarid Armenia](/wiki/Zakarid_Armenia "Zakarid Armenia") and [Mongol Armenia](/wiki/Mongol_Armenia "Mongol Armenia")

|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) | This section **does not [cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")** . Please help [improve this section](/wiki/Special:EditPage/Yerevan "Special:EditPage/Yerevan") by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners "Help:Referencing for beginners"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). *(May 2023)**([Learn how and when to remove this message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))* |

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Avan%2C_Hovhannes-chapel1.jpg/220px-Avan%2C_Hovhannes-chapel1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Avan,_Hovhannes-chapel1.jpg) The remains of Surp Hovhannes Chapel, dating back to the 12--13th centuries

After a brief Byzantine rule over Armenia between 1045 and 1064, the invading [Seljuks](/wiki/Seljuk_Empire "Seljuk Empire")---led by [Tughril](/wiki/Tughril "Tughril") and later by his successor [Alp Arslan](/wiki/Alp_Arslan "Alp Arslan")---ruled over the entire region, including Yerevan. However, with the establishment of the [Zakarid Principality of Armenia](/wiki/Zakarid_Armenia "Zakarid Armenia") in 1201 under the [Georgian](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Georgia "Kingdom of Georgia") protectorate, the Armenian territories of Yerevan and Lori had significantly grown. After the Mongols captured [Ani](/wiki/Ani "Ani") in 1236, Armenia turned into a [Mongol protectorate](/wiki/Mongol_Armenia "Mongol Armenia") as part of the [Ilkhanate](/wiki/Ilkhanate "Ilkhanate"), and the Zakarids became vassals to the [Mongols](/wiki/Mongol_Empire "Mongol Empire"). After the fall of the Ilkhanate in the mid-14th century, the Zakarid princes ruled over Lori, Shirak and the Ararat Plain until 1360 when they fell to the invading Turkic tribes.  

### Aq Qoyunlu and Kara Koyunlu tribes {#Aq_Qoyunlu_and_Kara_Koyunlu_tribes}

See also: [Kara Koyunlu](/wiki/Kara_Koyunlu "Kara Koyunlu")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Argavand_Tower_Back.JPG/170px-Argavand_Tower_Back.JPG)](/wiki/File:Argavand_Tower_Back.JPG) The [Mausoleum of Kara Koyunlu emirs](/wiki/Mausoleum_of_Kara_Koyunlu_emirs "Mausoleum of Kara Koyunlu emirs") in [Argavand](/wiki/Argavand,_Ararat "Argavand, Ararat"), near Yerevan

During the last quarter of the 14th century, the [Aq Qoyunlu](/wiki/Aq_Qoyunlu "Aq Qoyunlu") Sunni [Oghuz Turkic](/wiki/Oghuz_Turks "Oghuz Turks") tribe took over Armenia, including Yerevan. In 1400, [Timur](/wiki/Timur "Timur") invaded Armenia and Georgia, and captured more than 60,000 of the survived local people as slaves. Many districts including Yerevan were depopulated.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}

In 1410, Armenia fell under the control of the [Kara Koyunlu](/wiki/Kara_Koyunlu "Kara Koyunlu") Shia Oghuz Turkic tribe. According to the Armenian historian [Thomas of Metsoph](/wiki/Thomas_of_Metsoph "Thomas of Metsoph"), although the Kara Koyunlu levied heavy taxes against the Armenians, the early years of their rule were relatively peaceful and some reconstruction of towns took place.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-61)^ The Kara Koyunlus made Yerevan the centre of the newly formed *Chukhur Saad* administrative territory. The territory was named after a Turkic leader known as *Emir Saad*.{#cite_ref-61}

However, this peaceful period was shattered with the rise of [Qara Iskander](/wiki/Qara_Iskander "Qara Iskander") between 1420 and 1436, who reportedly made Armenia a "desert" and subjected it to "devastation and plunder, to slaughter, and captivity".^[\[58\]](#cite_note-62)^ The wars of Iskander and his eventual defeat against the [Timurids](/wiki/Timurid_Empire "Timurid Empire"), invited further destruction in Armenia, as many more Armenians were taken captive and sold into slavery and the land was subjected to outright pillaging, forcing many of them to leave the region.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-Kouymjian._Armenia,_p._5-63)^{#cite_ref-Kouymjian._Armenia,_p._5_63-0}

Following the fall of the [Armenian Kingdom of Cilicia](/wiki/Armenian_Kingdom_of_Cilicia "Armenian Kingdom of Cilicia") in 1375, the seat of the Armenian Church was transferred from [Sis](/wiki/Sis_(ancient_city) "Sis (ancient city)") back to [Vagharshapat](/wiki/Vagharshapat "Vagharshapat") near Yerevan in 1441. Thus, Yerevan became the main economic, cultural and administrative centre in Armenia.  

### Iranian rule {#Iranian_rule}

See also: [Iranian Armenia (1502--1828)](/wiki/Iranian_Armenia_(1502%E2%80%931828) "Iranian Armenia (1502–1828)") and [Erivan Khanate](/wiki/Erivan_Khanate "Erivan Khanate")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Chardin_Yerevan_1811.jpg/220px-Chardin_Yerevan_1811.jpg)](/wiki/File:Chardin_Yerevan_1811.jpg) An illustration of Yerevan by French traveler [Jean Chardin](/wiki/Jean_Chardin "Jean Chardin") in 1673 while he was travelling through the [Safavid Empire](/wiki/Safavid_Empire "Safavid Empire")

In 1501--02, most of the [Eastern Armenian](/wiki/Eastern_Armenia "Eastern Armenia") territories including Yerevan were swiftly conquered by the emerging [Safavid dynasty](/wiki/Safavid_dynasty "Safavid dynasty") of Iran led by Shah [Ismail I](/wiki/Ismail_I "Ismail I").^[\[60\]](#cite_note-64)^ Soon after in 1502, Yerevan became the centre of the [Erivan Province](/wiki/Erivan_Province_(Safavid_Empire) "Erivan Province (Safavid Empire)"), a new administrative territory of Iran formed by the Safavids. For the following 3 centuries, it remained, with brief intermissions, under the Iranian rule. Due to its strategic significance, Yerevan was initially often fought over, and passed back and forth, between the dominion of the rivaling [Iranian](/wiki/Safavid_Empire "Safavid Empire") and [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire"), until it permanently became controlled by the [Safavids](/wiki/Safavid_dynasty "Safavid dynasty"). In 1555, Iran had secured its legitimate possession over Yerevan with the Ottomans through the [Treaty of Amasya](/wiki/Peace_of_Amasya "Peace of Amasya").^[\[61\]](#cite_note-65)^{#cite_ref-65}

In 1582--1583, the Ottomans led by [Serdar Ferhad Pasha](/wiki/Serdar_Ferhad_Pasha "Serdar Ferhad Pasha") took brief control over Yerevan. Ferhad Pasha managed to build the [Erivan Fortress](/wiki/Erivan_Fortress "Erivan Fortress") on the ruins of one thousand-years old ancient Armenian fortress, on the shores of Hrazdan river.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-66)^ However, Ottoman control ended in 1604 when the Persians regained Yerevan as a result of [first Ottoman-Safavid War](/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Safavid_War_(1603%E2%80%9318) "Ottoman–Safavid War (1603–18)").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-66}

Shah [Abbas I of Persia](/wiki/Abbas_I_of_Persia "Abbas I of Persia") who ruled between 1588 and 1629, ordered the [deportation of hundreds of thousands of Armenians](/wiki/Great_Surgun "Great Surgun") including citizens from Yerevan to mainland [Persia](/wiki/Persia "Persia"). As a consequence, Yerevan significantly lost its Armenian population who had declined to 20%, while Muslims including Persians, Turks, Kurds and Tatars gained dominance with around 80% of the city's population. Muslims were either sedentary, semi-sedentary, or nomadic. Armenians mainly occupied the Kond neighbourhood of Yerevan and the rural suburbs around the city. However, the Armenians dominated over various professions and trade in the area and were of great economic significance to the Persian administration.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-v8f5-67)^{#cite_ref-v8f5_67-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/61/Kond_1.JPG/220px-Kond_1.JPG)](/wiki/File:Kond_1.JPG) [Kond](/wiki/Kond "Kond"), a historic neighbourhood of Yerevan, formed during the 17th century [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Erivan1796.jpg/220px-Erivan1796.jpg)](/wiki/File:Erivan1796.jpg) Yerevan in 1796 in the [Qajar era](/wiki/Qajar_dynasty "Qajar dynasty"), by G. Sergeevich. An Armenian church can be seen on the left and a Persian mosque on the right.

During the [second Ottoman-Safavid War](/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Safavid_War_(1623%E2%80%9339) "Ottoman–Safavid War (1623–39)"), Ottoman troops under the command of Sultan [Murad IV](/wiki/Murad_IV "Murad IV") conquered the city on 8 August 1635. Returning in triumph to [Constantinople](/wiki/Constantinople "Constantinople"), he opened the "Yerevan Kiosk" (*Revan Köşkü* ) in [Topkapı Palace](/wiki/Topkap%C4%B1_Palace "Topkapı Palace") in 1636. However, Iranian troops commanded by [Shah Safi](/wiki/Safi_of_Persia "Safi of Persia") retook Yerevan on 1 April 1636. As a result of the [Treaty of Zuhab](/wiki/Treaty_of_Zuhab "Treaty of Zuhab") in 1639, the Iranians reconfirmed their control over Eastern Armenia, including Yerevan. On 7 June 1679, [a devastating earthquake](/wiki/1679_Armenia_earthquake "1679 Armenia earthquake") razed the city to the ground.

In 1724, the Erivan Fortress was besieged by the Ottoman army.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ After a period of resistance, the fortress fell to the Turks. As a result of the Ottoman invasion, the Erivan Province of the [Safavids](/wiki/Safavid_dynasty "Safavid dynasty") was dissolved.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Following a brief period of Ottoman rule over Eastern Armenia between 1724 and 1736, and as a result of the fall of the Safavid dynasty in 1736, Yerevan along with the adjacent territories became part of the newly formed administrative territory of [Erivan Khanate](/wiki/Erivan_Khanate "Erivan Khanate") under the [Afsharid dynasty](/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty "Afsharid dynasty") of Iran, which encompassed an area of 15,000 square kilometres (5,800 square miles). The [Afsharids](/wiki/Afsharid_dynasty "Afsharid dynasty") controlled Eastern Armenia from the mid-1730s until the 1790s. Following the fall of the Afsharids, the [Qajar dynasty](/wiki/Qajar_dynasty "Qajar dynasty") of Iran took control of Eastern Armenia until 1828, when the region was [conquered](/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1826-1828) "Russo-Persian War (1826-1828)") by the Russian Empire after their victory over the Qajars that resulted in the [Treaty of Turkmenchay](/wiki/Treaty_of_Turkmenchay "Treaty of Turkmenchay") of 1828.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-68)^{#cite_ref-68}  

### Russian rule {#Russian_rule}

See also: [Armenian Oblast](/wiki/Armenian_Oblast "Armenian Oblast") and [Erivan Governorate](/wiki/Erivan_Governorate "Erivan Governorate")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Capture_of_Erivan_Fortress_by_Russia%2C_1827_%28by_Franz_Roubaud%29.jpg/220px-Capture_of_Erivan_Fortress_by_Russia%2C_1827_%28by_Franz_Roubaud%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Capture_of_Erivan_Fortress_by_Russia,_1827_(by_Franz_Roubaud).jpg) [Franz Roubaud](/wiki/Franz_Roubaud "Franz Roubaud")'s 1893 painting of the [Erivan Fortress](/wiki/Erivan_Fortress "Erivan Fortress") [siege of 1827](/wiki/Capture_of_Erivan "Capture of Erivan") by the Russian forces under leadership of [Ivan Paskevich](/wiki/Ivan_Paskevich "Ivan Paskevich") during the [Russo-Persian War (1826--28)](/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1826%E2%80%9328) "Russo-Persian War (1826–28)") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/%D5%81%D5%B8%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%A3%D5%B5%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B2%2C_%D4%B5%D6%80%D6%87%D5%A1%D5%B6.jpg/220px-%D5%81%D5%B8%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%A3%D5%B5%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B2%2C_%D4%B5%D6%80%D6%87%D5%A1%D5%B6.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D5%81%D5%B8%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%A3%D5%B5%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B2,_%D4%B5%D6%80%D6%87%D5%A1%D5%B6.jpg) Dzoragyugh neighbourhood of old Yerevan in the 19th century

During the second [Russo-Persian War](/wiki/Russo-Persian_Wars "Russo-Persian Wars") of the 19th century, the [Russo-Persian War of 1826--28](/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1826%E2%80%9328) "Russo-Persian War (1826–28)"), Yerevan [was captured](/wiki/Capture_of_Erivan "Capture of Erivan") by Russian troops under general [Ivan Paskevich](/wiki/Ivan_Paskevich "Ivan Paskevich") on 1 October 1827.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-SAE-40)^^[\[65\]](#cite_note-69)^^[\[66\]](#cite_note-70)^ It was formally ceded by the Iranians in 1828, following the [Treaty of Turkmenchay](/wiki/Treaty_of_Turkmenchay "Treaty of Turkmenchay").^[\[67\]](#cite_note-71)^ After 3 centuries of Iranian occupation, Yereven along with the rest of [Eastern Armenia](/wiki/Eastern_Armenia "Eastern Armenia") designated as the "[Armenian Oblast](/wiki/Armenian_Oblast "Armenian Oblast")", became part of the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"), a [period](/wiki/Russian_Armenia "Russian Armenia") that would last until the collapse of the Empire in 1917.{#cite_ref-71}

Although not mentioned specifically by name, article XV of the Turkmenchay treaty was intended solely for the repatriation of those Armenians whose ancestors had been forcibly relocated to Iran in the early 17th century during the Safavid period. The Russians sponsored the resettlement process of the Armenian population from Persia and Turkey and spread announcements in Armenian villages.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBournoutian198020-72)^ Due to the resettlement, the percentage of the Armenian population of Yerevan increased from 28% to 53.8%. The resettlement was intended to create [Russian](/wiki/Russia "Russia") power bridgehead in the Middle East.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-73)^ In 1829, Armenian repatriates from Persia were resettled in the city and a new quarter was built.{#cite_ref-73}

Yerevan served as the seat of the newly formed [Armenian Oblast](/wiki/Armenian_Oblast "Armenian Oblast") between 1828 and 1840. By the time of [Nicholas I](/wiki/Nicholas_I_of_Russia "Nicholas I of Russia")'s visit in 1837, Yerevan had become an *[uezd](/wiki/Erivan_Uyezd "Erivan Uyezd")* ("county"). In 1840, the Armenian Oblast was dissolved and its territory incorporated into a new larger province; the [Georgia-Imeretia Governorate](/wiki/Georgia-Imeretia_Governorate "Georgia-Imeretia Governorate"). In 1850 the territory of the former oblast was reorganized into the [Erivan Governorate](/wiki/Erivan_Governorate "Erivan Governorate"), covering an area of 28,000 square kilometres (11,000 square miles). Yerevan was the centre of the newly established governorate.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Surb_grigor_lusavorich.png/220px-Surb_grigor_lusavorich.png)](/wiki/File:Surb_grigor_lusavorich.png) [Saint Gregory Church](/wiki/Saint_Gregory_the_Illuminator_Church,_Yerevan "Saint Gregory the Illuminator Church, Yerevan"), opened in 1900 (later destroyed in 1939) [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Erivan_Main_Square_1916.jpg/220px-Erivan_Main_Square_1916.jpg)](/wiki/File:Erivan_Main_Square_1916.jpg) The [Main Square](/wiki/Republic_Square,_Yerevan "Republic Square, Yerevan") of Yerevan, 1916

At that period, Yerevan was a small town with narrow roads and alleys, including the central quarter of *Shahar* , the *Ghantar* commercial centre, and the residential neighbourhoods of Kond, Dzoragyugh, Nork and Shentagh. During the 1840s and the 1850s, many schools were opened in the city. However, the first major plan of Yerevan was adopted in 1856, during which, Saint Hripsime and Saint Gayane women's colleges were founded and the [English Park](/wiki/English_Park,_Yerevan "English Park, Yerevan") was opened. In 1863, the [Astafyan Street](/wiki/Abovyan_Street "Abovyan Street") was redeveloped and opened. In 1874, Zacharia Gevorkian opened Yerevan's first printing house, while the first theatre opened its doors in 1879.

On 1 October 1879, Yerevan was granted the status of a city through a decree issued by [Alexander II of Russia](/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia "Alexander II of Russia"). In 1881, The Yerevan Teachers' Seminary and the Yerevan Brewery were opened, followed by the Tairyan's wine and brandy factory in 1887. Other factories for alcoholic beverages and mineral water were opened during the 1890s. The monumental church of [Saint Gregory the Illuminator](/wiki/Saint_Gregory_the_Illuminator_Church,_Yerevan "Saint Gregory the Illuminator Church, Yerevan") was opened in 1900. Electricity and telephone lines were introduced to the city in 1907 and 1913 respectively. When British traveller [H. F. B. Lynch](/wiki/H._F._B._Lynch "H. F. B. Lynch") visited Yerevan in 1893--1894, he considered it an [Oriental](/wiki/Orient "Orient") city.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-Bournoutian2018Yerevan-74)^ However, this started to change in the first decade of the 20th century, in the penultimate decade of Imperial Russian rule, when the city grew and altered dramatically.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-Bournoutian2018Yerevan-74)^ In general, Yerevan rapidly grew under Russian rule, both economically and politically. Old buildings were torn down and new buildings of European style were erected.{#cite_ref-Bournoutian2018Yerevan_74-1}

At the beginning of the 20th century, Yerevan city's population was over 29,000.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-75)^ In 1902, a railway line linked Yerevan with [Alexandropol](/wiki/Alexandropol "Alexandropol"), [Tiflis](/wiki/Tiflis "Tiflis") and [Julfa](/wiki/Julfa,_Azerbaijan_(town) "Julfa, Azerbaijan (town)"). In the same year, Yerevan's first public library was opened. In 1905, the grandnephew of [Napoleon I](/wiki/Napoleon_I "Napoleon I"); prince Louis Joseph Jérôme Napoléon (1864--1932) was appointed as governor of Yerevan province.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-76)^ In 1913, for the first time in the city, a telephone line with eighty subscribers became operational.{#cite_ref-76}

Yerevan served as the centre of the governorate until 1917, when Erivan governorate was dissolved with the collapse of the Russian Empire.  

### Brief independence {#Brief_independence}

Main article: [First Republic of Armenia](/wiki/First_Republic_of_Armenia "First Republic of Armenia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Government-House-of-Republic-of-Armenia-1918-1920.jpg/220px-Government-House-of-Republic-of-Armenia-1918-1920.jpg)](/wiki/File:Government-House-of-Republic-of-Armenia-1918-1920.jpg) Government house of [Armenia](/wiki/First_Republic_of_Armenia "First Republic of Armenia") from where [Aram Manukian](/wiki/Aram_Manukian "Aram Manukian") declared independence in May 1918 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/May_28_1919_celebration_Yerevan.jpg/220px-May_28_1919_celebration_Yerevan.jpg)](/wiki/File:May_28_1919_celebration_Yerevan.jpg) Celebration of the first anniversary of the [First Republic of Armenia](/wiki/First_Republic_of_Armenia "First Republic of Armenia") in 1919

At the beginning of the 20th century, Yerevan was a small city with a population of 30,000.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-Univ-77)^ In 1917, the Russian Empire ended with the [October Revolution](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution"). In the aftermath, Armenian, Georgian and Muslim leaders of [Transcaucasia](/wiki/South_Caucasus "South Caucasus") united to form the [Transcaucasian Federation](/wiki/Transcaucasian_Democratic_Federative_Republic "Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic") and proclaimed [Transcaucasia](/wiki/Transcaucasia "Transcaucasia")'s [secession](/wiki/Secession "Secession").{#cite_ref-Univ_77-0}

The Federation, however, was short-lived. After gaining control over [Alexandropol](/wiki/Gyumri "Gyumri"), the Turkish army was advancing towards the south and east to eliminate the center of Armenian resistance based in Yerevan. On 21 May 1918, the Turks started their campaign moving towards Yerevan via Sardarabad. [Catholicos](/wiki/Catholicos_of_All_Armenians "Catholicos of All Armenians") [Gevorg V](/wiki/George_V_of_Armenia "George V of Armenia") ordered that church bells peal for 6 days as Armenians from all walks of life -- peasants, poets, blacksmiths, and even the clergymen -- rallied to form organized military units.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-78)^ Civilians, including children, aided in the effort as well, as "Carts drawn by oxen, water buffalo, and cows jammed the roads bringing food, provisions, ammunition, and volunteers from the vicinity" of Yerevan.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-79)^{#cite_ref-79}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Plan_of_Yerevan_1920.jpg/220px-Plan_of_Yerevan_1920.jpg)](/wiki/File:Plan_of_Yerevan_1920.jpg) Map of Yerevan in 1920, made before the Soviet reconstruction of the city by [Alexander Tamanyan](/wiki/Alexander_Tamanyan "Alexander Tamanyan") in 1924. Taken looking west, with the [Hrazdan River](/wiki/Hrazdan_River "Hrazdan River") at the top rather than the left side.

By the end of May 1918, Armenians were able to defeat the Turkish army in the battles of [Sardarabad](/wiki/Battle_of_Sardarabad "Battle of Sardarabad"), [Abaran](/wiki/Battle_of_Abaran "Battle of Abaran") and [Karakilisa](/wiki/Battle_of_Karakilisa "Battle of Karakilisa"). Thus, on 28 May 1918, the [Dashnak](/wiki/Armenian_Revolutionary_Federation "Armenian Revolutionary Federation") leader [Aram Manukian](/wiki/Aram_Manukian "Aram Manukian") declared the independence of Armenia. Subsequently, Yerevan became the capital and the center of the newly founded [Republic of Armenia](/wiki/First_Republic_of_Armenia "First Republic of Armenia"), although the members of the [Armenian National Council](/wiki/Armenian_Congress_of_Eastern_Armenians "Armenian Congress of Eastern Armenians") were yet to stay in [Tiflis](/wiki/Tbilisi "Tbilisi") until their arrival in Yerevan to form the government in the summer of the same year.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-80)^ Armenia became a [parliamentary republic](/wiki/Parliamentary_republic "Parliamentary republic") with four administrative divisions. The capital Yerevan was part of the *Araratian Province* . At the time, Yerevan received more than 75,000 refugees from [Western Armenia](/wiki/Western_Armenia "Western Armenia"), who escaped the massacres perpetrated by the Ottoman Turks during the [Armenian genocide](/wiki/Armenian_genocide "Armenian genocide").{#cite_ref-80}

On 26 May 1919, the government passed a law to open the [Yerevan State University](/wiki/Yerevan_State_University "Yerevan State University"), which was located on the main [Astafyan (now Abovyan) street](/wiki/Abovyan_Street "Abovyan Street") of Yerevan.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

After the signing of the [Treaty of Sèvres](/wiki/Treaty_of_S%C3%A8vres "Treaty of Sèvres") in 1920, Armenia was granted formal international recognition. The [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States"), as well as many South American countries, officially opened diplomatic channels with the government of independent Armenia. Yerevan had also opened representatives in [Great Britain](/wiki/Great_Britain "Great Britain"), [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"), [Greece](/wiki/Greece "Greece"), [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran") and [Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

However, after the short period of independence, Yerevan fell to the [Bolsheviks](/wiki/Bolshevik "Bolshevik"), and Armenia was incorporated into [Soviet Russia](/wiki/Soviet_Russia "Soviet Russia") on 2 December 1920. Although nationalist forces managed to retake the city in February 1921 and successfully released all the imprisoned political and military figures, the city's nationalist elite were once again defeated by the [Soviet forces](/wiki/Soviet_forces "Soviet forces") on 2 April 1921.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

### Soviet rule {#Soviet_rule}

See also: [Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Armenian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Mayr_Hayrenik.jpg/220px-Mayr_Hayrenik.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mayr_Hayrenik.jpg) [Mother Armenia](/wiki/Mother_Armenia "Mother Armenia") erected in 1967, replacing the monumental statue of [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/David_of_Sasun_Yerevan.jpg/220px-David_of_Sasun_Yerevan.jpg)](/wiki/File:David_of_Sasun_Yerevan.jpg) *[David of Sassoun](/wiki/David_of_Sassoun_(statue) "David of Sassoun (statue)")* and the [Yerevan railway station](/wiki/Yerevan_railway_station "Yerevan railway station").

The [Red Soviet Army](/wiki/Red_Army "Red Army") invaded Armenia on 29 November 1920 from the northeast. On 2 December 1920, Yerevan along with the other territories of the [Republic of Armenia](/wiki/First_Republic_of_Armenia "First Republic of Armenia"), became part of [Soviet Russia](/wiki/Soviet_Russia "Soviet Russia"), known as the [Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Armenian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic"). However, the Armenian SSR formed the Transcaucasian SFSR (TSFSR) together with the [Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Georgian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic") and the [Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Azerbaijan_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic"), between 1922 and 1936.

Under the Soviet rule, Yerevan became the first among the cities in the Soviet Union for which a general plan was developed. The "General Plan of Yerevan" developed by the academician [Alexander Tamanian](/wiki/Alexander_Tamanian "Alexander Tamanian"), was approved in 1924. It was initially designed for a population of 150,000.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The city was quickly transformed into a modern industrial metropolis of over one million people.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ New educational, scientific and cultural institutions were founded as well.

Tamanian incorporated national traditions with contemporary urban construction. His design presented a radial-circular arrangement that overlaid the existing city and incorporated much of its existing street plan. As a result, many historic buildings were demolished, including churches, mosques, the [Erivan Fortress](/wiki/Erivan_Fortress "Erivan Fortress"), baths, bazaars and [caravanserais](/wiki/Caravanserai "Caravanserai"). Many of the districts around central Yerevan were named after former Armenian communities that were destroyed by the [Ottoman Turks](/wiki/Ottoman_Turks "Ottoman Turks") during the [Armenian genocide](/wiki/Armenian_genocide "Armenian genocide"). The districts of Arabkir, Malatia-Sebastia and Nork Marash, for example, were named after the towns [Arabkir](/wiki/Arapgir "Arapgir"), [Malatya](/wiki/Malatya "Malatya"), [Sebastia](/wiki/Sivas,_Turkey "Sivas, Turkey"), and [Marash](/wiki/Kahramanmara%C5%9F "Kahramanmaraş"), respectively. After the end of [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), [German](/wiki/Germans "Germans") [POWs](/wiki/POW "POW") were used to help in the construction of new buildings and structures, such as the Kievyan Bridge.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Within the years, the central [Kentron district](/wiki/Kentron_district "Kentron district") has become the most developed area in Yerevan, something that created a significant gap compared with other districts in the city. Most of the educational, cultural and scientific institutions were centred in the Kentron district.

In 1965, during the commemorations of the fiftieth anniversary of the Armenian Genocide, Yerevan was the location of a [demonstration](/wiki/1965_Yerevan_demonstrations "1965 Yerevan demonstrations"), the first such demonstration in the Soviet Union, to demand recognition of the Genocide by the Soviet authorities.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-81)^ In 1968, the city's 2,750th anniversary was commemorated.{#cite_ref-81}

Yerevan played a key role in the Armenian national democratic movement that emerged during the [Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail Gorbachev") era of the 1980s. The reforms of [Glasnost](/wiki/Glasnost "Glasnost") and [Perestroika](/wiki/Perestroika "Perestroika") opened questions on issues such as the status of Nagorno-Karabakh, the environment, [Russification](/wiki/Russification "Russification"), corruption, democracy, and eventually independence. At the beginning of 1988, nearly one million Armenians from several regions of Armenia engaged in demonstrations concerning these subjects, centered in the city's Theater Square (currently [Freedom Square](/wiki/Freedom_Square,_Yerevan "Freedom Square, Yerevan")).^[\[78\]](#cite_note-82)^{#cite_ref-82}  

### Modern independence {#Modern_independence}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Yerevan_at_night.jpg/220px-Yerevan_at_night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_at_night.jpg) Nighttime view of Yerevan in September 2013

Following the [dissolution of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet Union"), Yerevan became the capital of Armenia on 21 September 1991.^[\[79\]](#cite_note-BJFAO-83)^ Maintaining supplies of gas and electricity proved difficult; constant electricity was not restored until 1996 amidst the chaos of the badly instigated and planned transition to a [market-based economy](/wiki/Market_economy "Market economy").{#cite_ref-BJFAO_83-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Elite_Plaza_Business_Center_at_Night.jpg/220px-Elite_Plaza_Business_Center_at_Night.jpg)](/wiki/File:Elite_Plaza_Business_Center_at_Night.jpg) The redeveloped Yerevan downtown is the commercial and business centre of the city.

Since 2000, central Yerevan has been transformed into a vast construction site, with cranes erected all over the Kentron district. Officially, the scores of multi-storied buildings are part of large-scale urban planning projects. Roughly $1.8 billion was spent on such construction in 2006, according to the national statistical service.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Prices for downtown apartments have increased by about ten times during the first decade of the 21st century.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Many new streets and avenues were opened, such as the Argishti street, Italy street, Saralanj Avenue, Monte Melkonian Avenue, and the [Northern Avenue](/wiki/Northern_Avenue_(Yerevan) "Northern Avenue (Yerevan)").

However, as a result of this construction boom, the majority of the historic buildings located on the central [Aram Street](/wiki/Aram_Street "Aram Street"), were either entirely destroyed or transformed into modern residential buildings through the construction of additional floors. Only a few structures were preserved, mainly in the portion that extends between [Abovyan Street](/wiki/Abovyan_Street "Abovyan Street") and [Mashtots Avenue](/wiki/Mashtots_Avenue "Mashtots Avenue").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Yerevan_buildings_and_Ararat.jpg/250px-Yerevan_buildings_and_Ararat.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_buildings_and_Ararat.jpg) Panoramic view from the [Kentron district](/wiki/Kentron_district "Kentron district")

The first major post-independence protest in Yerevan took place in September 1996, after the announcement of incumbent [Levon Ter-Petrosyan](/wiki/Levon_Ter-Petrosyan "Levon Ter-Petrosyan")'s victory in the [presidential election](/wiki/Armenian_presidential_election,_1996 "Armenian presidential election, 1996"). Major opposition parties of the time, consolidated around the former [Karabakh Committee](/wiki/Karabakh_Committee "Karabakh Committee") member and former Prime Minister [Vazgen Manukyan](/wiki/Vazgen_Manukyan "Vazgen Manukyan"), organized mass demonstrations between 23 and 25 September, claiming electoral fraud by Ter-Petrosyan.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-84)^ An estimated of 200,000 people gathered in the [Freedom Square](/wiki/Freedom_Square,_Yerevan "Freedom Square, Yerevan") to protest the election results.^[\[81\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAstourian200145-85)^ After a series of riot and violent protests around the Parliament building on 25 September, the government sent tanks and troops to Yerevan to enforce the ban on rallies and demonstrations on the following day.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-86)^ Prime Minister [Vazgen Sargsyan](/wiki/Vazgen_Sargsyan "Vazgen Sargsyan") and Minister of National Security [Serzh Sargsyan](/wiki/Serzh_Sargsyan "Serzh Sargsyan") announced on the [Public Television of Armenia](/wiki/Public_Television_company_of_Armenia "Public Television company of Armenia") that their respective agencies have prevented an attempted [coup d'état](/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "Coup d'état").^[\[83\]](#cite_note-Jeffries-87)^{#cite_ref-Jeffries_87-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Garegin_Nzhdeh_monument%2C_Yerevan%2C_ArmAg_%2814%29.jpg/220px-Garegin_Nzhdeh_monument%2C_Yerevan%2C_ArmAg_%2814%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Garegin_Nzhdeh_monument,_Yerevan,_ArmAg_(14).jpg) Statue of Armenian nationalist figure [Garegin Nzhdeh](/wiki/Garegin_Nzhdeh "Garegin Nzhdeh") in central Yerevan

In February 2008, [unrest in the capital](/wiki/2008_Armenian_presidential_election_protests "2008 Armenian presidential election protests") between the authorities and opposition demonstrators led by ex-President Levon Ter-Petrosyan took place after the [2008 Armenian presidential election](/wiki/Armenian_presidential_election,_2008 "Armenian presidential election, 2008"). The events resulted in 10 deaths^[\[84\]](#cite_note-ArmLibApr14-88)^ and a subsequent 20-day [state of emergency](/wiki/State_of_emergency "State of emergency") declared by President [Robert Kocharyan](/wiki/Robert_Kocharyan "Robert Kocharyan").^[\[85\]](#cite_note-BBCMar2-89)^{#cite_ref-BBCMar2_89-0}

In July 2016, a group of armed men calling themselves the *Daredevils of Sassoun* ([Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language"): Սասնա Ծռեր *Sasna Tsrrer* ) [stormed a police station in Erebuni District of Yerevan](/wiki/2016_Yerevan_hostage_crisis "2016 Yerevan hostage crisis"), taking several hostages, demanding the release of opposition leader [Jirair Sefilian](/wiki/Jirair_Sefilian "Jirair Sefilian") and the resignation of President Serzh Sargsyan. 3 policeman were killed as a result of the attack.^[\[86\]](#cite_note-90)^ Many anti-government protestors held rallies in solidarity with the gunmen.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-ie-91)^ However, after 2 weeks of negotiations, the crisis ended and the gunmen surrendered.{#cite_ref-ie_91-0}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

### Topography and cityscape {#Topography_and_cityscape}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Yerevan_in_Armenia.svg/220px-Yerevan_in_Armenia.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_in_Armenia.svg) Plan of Yerevan in Armenia [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Hrazdan_river_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Hrazdan_river_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hrazdan_river_-_panoramio.jpg) [Hrazdan River](/wiki/Hrazdan_River "Hrazdan River") flowing through Yerevan

Yerevan has an average height of 990 m (3,248.03 ft), with a minimum of 865 m (2,837.93 ft) and a maximum of 1,390 m (4,560.37 ft) [above sea level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level") in its southwestern and northeastern sections, respectively.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-Azatian-92)^ It is among the fifty highest cities in the world with over 1 million inhabitants.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}

Yerevan is located on the banks of the [Hrazdan River](/wiki/Hrazdan_River "Hrazdan River"), northeast of the [Ararat Plain](/wiki/Ararat_Plain "Ararat Plain"), in the central-western part of the country. The upper part of the city is surrounded with mountains on three sides while it descends to the banks of the river [Hrazdan](/wiki/Hrazdan_River "Hrazdan River") at the south. The Hrazdan divides Yerevan into two parts through a picturesque canyon.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/%D4%B5%D6%80%D5%A5%D6%82%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%AB_%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%B6%D5%A1%D5%BA%D5%A1%D5%BF%D5%AF%D5%A5%D6%80_%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%B7%D5%A1%D5%AC%D5%B8%D5%B5%D5%BD%D5%AB%D5%B6.JPG/220px-%D4%B5%D6%80%D5%A5%D6%82%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%AB_%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%B6%D5%A1%D5%BA%D5%A1%D5%BF%D5%AF%D5%A5%D6%80_%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%B7%D5%A1%D5%AC%D5%B8%D5%B5%D5%BD%D5%AB%D5%B6.JPG)](/wiki/File:%D4%B5%D6%80%D5%A5%D6%82%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%AB_%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%B6%D5%A1%D5%BA%D5%A1%D5%BF%D5%AF%D5%A5%D6%80_%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%B7%D5%A1%D5%AC%D5%B8%D5%B5%D5%BD%D5%AB%D5%B6.JPG) Yerevan is situated in the northeastern part of the Ararat Plain.

The city is situated at the heart of the [Armenian Highland](/wiki/Armenian_Highland "Armenian Highland").^[\[90\]](#cite_note-94)^ Historically, Yerevan was located in the Kotayk canton ([Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language"): Կոտայք գավառ *Kotayk gavar* , not to be confused with the current [Kotayk Province](/wiki/Kotayk_Province "Kotayk Province")) of the [Ayrarat](/wiki/Ayrarat "Ayrarat") province of historic [Armenia Major](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Armenia_(antiquity) "Kingdom of Armenia (antiquity)").{#cite_ref-94}

According to the current administrative division of Armenia, Yerevan is not part of any *[marz](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Armenia "Administrative divisions of Armenia")* ("province") and has special administrative status as the country's capital. It is bordered by [Kotayk Province](/wiki/Kotayk_Province "Kotayk Province") to the north and the east, [Ararat Province](/wiki/Ararat_Province "Ararat Province") to the south and the south-west, [Armavir Province](/wiki/Armavir_Province "Armavir Province") to the west and [Aragatsotn Province](/wiki/Aragatsotn_Province "Aragatsotn Province") to the north-west.

The [Erebuni State Reserve](/wiki/Erebuni_State_Reserve "Erebuni State Reserve"), formed in 1981, is located around 8 km southeast of the city centre within the [Erebuni District](/wiki/Erebuni_District "Erebuni District") of the city. At a height between 1300 and 1450 meters above sea level, the reserve occupies an area of 120 hectares, mainly consisting of semi-deserted mountain-steppes.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}  

### Climate {#Climate}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Yerevan_2012_February.JPG/220px-Yerevan_2012_February.JPG)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_2012_February.JPG) Winter view of Yerevan

Yerevan features a [continental](/wiki/Continental_climate "Continental climate") influenced [steppe climate](/wiki/Steppe_climate "Steppe climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *BSk* or "cold semi-arid climate", [Trewartha climate classification](/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification "Trewartha climate classification") *BSao* ), with long, hot, dry summers and short, but cold and snowy winters. This is attributed to Yerevan being on a plain surrounded by mountains and to its distance from the sea and its moderating effects. The summers are usually very hot with the temperature in August reaching up to 40 °C (104 °F), and winters generally carry snowfall and freezing temperatures with January often being as cold as −15 °C (5 °F) and lower. The amount of [precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology) "Precipitation (meteorology)") is small, amounting annually to about 318 millimetres (12.5 in). Yerevan experiences an average of 2,700 sunshine hours per year.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-Azatian-92)^ On 12 July 2018, Yerevan recorded a temperature of 43.7 °C (110.7 °F), which is the joint highest temperature to have ever been recorded in Armenia.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-BAMS2018-96)^{#cite_ref-BAMS2018_96-0}
