### Architecture {#Architecture}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/2014_Erywa%C5%84%2C_Ulica_Arama_3_%2801%29.jpg/220px-2014_Erywa%C5%84%2C_Ulica_Arama_3_%2801%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2014_Erywa%C5%84,_Ulica_Arama_3_(01).jpg) Traditional 19th-century buildings of Yerevan on [Aram Street](/wiki/Aram_Street "Aram Street")

The [Yerevan TV Tower](/wiki/Yerevan_TV_Tower "Yerevan TV Tower") is the tallest structure in the city and one of the tallest structures in the [South Caucasus](/wiki/South_Caucasus "South Caucasus").

The [Republic Square](/wiki/Republic_Square,_Yerevan "Republic Square, Yerevan"), the [Yerevan Opera Theatre](/wiki/Yerevan_Opera_Theatre "Yerevan Opera Theatre"), and the [Yerevan Cascade](/wiki/Yerevan_Cascade "Yerevan Cascade") are among the main landmarks at the centre of Yerevan, mainly developed based on the original design of architect [Alexander Tamanian](/wiki/Alexander_Tamanian "Alexander Tamanian"), and the revised plan of architect Jim Torosyan.

A major redevelopment process has been launched in Yerevan since 2000. As a result, many historic structures have been demolished and replaced with new buildings. This urban renewal plan has been met with opposition^[\[95\]](#cite_note-99)^ and criticism from some residents, as the projects destroy historic buildings dating back to the period of the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire"), and often leave residents homeless.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-100)^^[\[97\]](#cite_note-101)^^[\[98\]](#cite_note-102)^ Downtown houses deemed too small are increasingly demolished and replaced by high-rise buildings.{#cite_ref-102}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Yerevan_Northern_2010.jpg/220px-Yerevan_Northern_2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_Northern_2010.jpg) Modern buildings on the [Northern Avenue](/wiki/Northern_Avenue_(Yerevan) "Northern Avenue (Yerevan)")

The [Saint Gregory Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Gregory_the_Illuminator_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Gregory the Illuminator Cathedral, Yerevan"), the new building of [Yerevan City Council](/wiki/Yerevan_City_Council "Yerevan City Council"), the new section of [Matenadaran](/wiki/Matenadaran "Matenadaran") institute, the new terminal of [Zvartnots International Airport](/wiki/Zvartnots_International_Airport "Zvartnots International Airport"), the [Cafesjian Center for the Arts](/wiki/Cafesjian_Museum_of_Art "Cafesjian Museum of Art") at the Cascade, the [Northern Avenue](/wiki/Northern_Avenue,_Yerevan "Northern Avenue, Yerevan"), and the new government complex of ministries are among the major construction projects fulfilled during the first two decades of the 21st century.

[Aram Street](/wiki/Aram_Street "Aram Street") of old Yerevan and the newly built [Northern Avenue](/wiki/Northern_Avenue_(Yerevan) "Northern Avenue (Yerevan)") are respectively among the notable examples featuring the traditional and modern architectural characteristics of Yerevan.

As of May 2017, Yerevan is home to 4,883 residential apartment buildings, and 65,199 street lamps installed on 39,799 [street light](/wiki/Street_light "Street light") posts, covering a total length of 1,514 km. The city has 1,080 streets with a total length of 750 km.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-103)^{#cite_ref-103}  

### Parks {#Parks}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Lovers%27_Park%2C_Yerevan.jpg/220px-Lovers%27_Park%2C_Yerevan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lovers%27_Park,_Yerevan.jpg) The [Lovers' Park](/wiki/Lovers%27_Park "Lovers' Park")

Yerevan is a densely built city but still offers several public parks throughout its districts, graced with mid-sized green gardens. The public park of Erebuni District along with its artificial lake is the oldest garden in the city. Occupying an area of 17 hectares, the origins of the park and the artificial lake date back to the period of king [Argishti I of Urartu](/wiki/Argishti_I_of_Urartu "Argishti I of Urartu") during the 8th century BCE. In 2011, the garden was entirely remodelled and named as [Lyon Park](/wiki/Lyon_Park,_Yerevan "Lyon Park, Yerevan"), to become a symbol of the partnership between the cities of [Lyon](/wiki/Lyon "Lyon") and Yerevan.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-104)^{#cite_ref-104}

The [Lovers' Park](/wiki/Lovers%27_Park "Lovers' Park") on [Marshal Baghramyan Avenue](/wiki/Baghramyan_Avenue "Baghramyan Avenue") and the [English Park](/wiki/English_Park,_Yerevan "English Park, Yerevan") at the centre of the city, dating back to the 18th and 19th centuries respectively, are among the most popular parks in Yerevan. The [Yerevan Botanical Garden](/wiki/Yerevan_Botanical_Garden "Yerevan Botanical Garden") (opened in 1935), the [Victory Park](/wiki/Victory_Park,_Yerevan "Victory Park, Yerevan") (opened in the 1950s) and the [Circular Park](/wiki/Circular_Park "Circular Park") are among the largest green spaces of the city.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Swan_Lake%2C_Yerevan-12.jpg/220px-Swan_Lake%2C_Yerevan-12.jpg)](/wiki/File:Swan_Lake,_Yerevan-12.jpg) The *Swan Lake*

Opened in the 1960s, the Yerevan Opera Theatre Park along with its artificial *Swan Lake* is also among the favourite green spaces of the city. In 2019 some of the public space of the park leased to restaurants was reclaimed allowing for improved landscape design.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-105)^ A public ice-skating arena is operated in the park's lake area during winters.{#cite_ref-105}

The [Yerevan Lake](/wiki/Yerevan_Lake "Yerevan Lake") is an artificial reservoir opened in 1967 on [Hrazdan](/wiki/Hrazdan_River "Hrazdan River") riverbed at the south of the city centre, with a surface of 0.65 km^2^ (0.25 sq mi).

Each administrative district of Yerevan has its own public park, such as the [Buenos Aires Park](/wiki/Buenos_Aires_Park "Buenos Aires Park") and [Tumanyan Park](/wiki/Tumanyan_Park "Tumanyan Park") in [Ajapnyak](/wiki/Ajapnyak_District "Ajapnyak District"), Komitas Park in [Shengavit](/wiki/Shengavit_District "Shengavit District"), Vahan Zatikian Park in [Malatia-Sebastia](/wiki/Malatia-Sebastia_District "Malatia-Sebastia District"), David Anhaght Park in [Kanaker-Zeytun](/wiki/Kanaker-Zeytun_District "Kanaker-Zeytun District"), the Family Park in [Avan](/wiki/Avan_District "Avan District"), and Fridtjof Nansen Park in [Nor Nork](/wiki/Nor_Nork_District "Nor Nork District").  

Politics and government {#Politics_and_government}
--------------------------------------------------

### Capital {#Capital}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/2014_Erywa%C5%84%2C_Budynek_Zgromadzenia_Narodowego_Republiki_Armenii.jpg/250px-2014_Erywa%C5%84%2C_Budynek_Zgromadzenia_Narodowego_Republiki_Armenii.jpg)](/wiki/File:2014_Erywa%C5%84,_Budynek_Zgromadzenia_Narodowego_Republiki_Armenii.jpg) The [National Assembly of Armenia](/wiki/National_Assembly_(Armenia) "National Assembly (Armenia)") on [Baghramyan Avenue](/wiki/Baghramyan_Avenue "Baghramyan Avenue")

Yerevan has been the capital of Armenia since the independence of the First Republic in 1918. Situated in the Ararat Plain, the historic lands of Armenia, it served as the best logical choice for capital of the young republic at the time.

When Armenia became a republic of the Soviet Union, Yerevan remained as capital and accommodated all the political and diplomatic institutions in the republic. In 1991 with the independence of Armenia, Yerevan continued with its status as the political and cultural centre of the country, being home to all the national institutions: the [Government House](/wiki/Government_House,_Yerevan "Government House, Yerevan"), the [National Assembly](/wiki/National_Assembly_Building_of_Armenia "National Assembly Building of Armenia"), the [Presidential Palace](/wiki/Presidential_Palace,_Yerevan "Presidential Palace, Yerevan"), the [Central Bank](/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Armenia "Central Bank of Armenia"), the [Constitutional Court](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Armenia "Constitutional Court of Armenia"), all ministries, judicial bodies and other government organizations.  

### Municipality {#Municipality}

See also: [List of mayors of Yerevan](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Yerevan "List of mayors of Yerevan")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Yerevan_city_hall%2C_vodka_%26_brandy_factory.jpg/220px-Yerevan_city_hall%2C_vodka_%26_brandy_factory.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_city_hall,_vodka_%26_brandy_factory.jpg) [Yerevan City Hall](/wiki/Yerevan_City_Council "Yerevan City Council") (right)

Yerevan received the status of a city on 1 October 1879, upon a decree issued by Tsar [Alexander II of Russia](/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia "Alexander II of Russia"). The first city council formed was headed by Hovhannes Ghorghanyan, who became the first mayor of Yerevan.

The Constitution of the Republic of Armenia adopted on 5 July 1995, granted Yerevan the status of a [marz](/wiki/Marz_(Armenia) "Marz (Armenia)") (մարզ, province).^[\[102\]](#cite_note-autogenerated1-106)^ Therefore, Yerevan functions similarly to the provinces of Armenia with a few specifications.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-107)^ The administrative authority of Yerevan is thus represented by:{#cite_ref-107}

* the mayor, appointed by the President (who can remove him at any moment) upon the recommendation of the Prime Minister,^[\[102\]](#cite_note-autogenerated1-106)^ alongside a group of four deputy mayors heading eleven ministries (of which financial, transport, urban development etc.),^[\[104\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}
* the [Yerevan City Council](/wiki/Yerevan_City_Council "Yerevan City Council"), regrouping the Heads of community districts under the authority of the mayor,^[\[105\]](#cite_note-109)^{#cite_ref-109}
* twelve "community districts", with each having its own leader and their elected councils.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-110)^ Yerevan has a principal city hall and twelve deputy mayors of districts.{#cite_ref-110}

In the modified Constitution of 27 November 2005, Yerevan city was turned into a "community" (համայնք, *hamaynk* ); since, the Constitution declares that this community has to be led by a mayor, elected directly or indirectly, and that the city needs to be governed by a specific law.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-111)^ The first election of the Yerevan City Council took place in [2009](/wiki/Yerevan_City_Council_election,_2009 "Yerevan City Council election, 2009") and won by the ruling [Republican Party of Armenia](/wiki/Republican_Party_of_Armenia "Republican Party of Armenia").^[\[108\]](#cite_note-112)^^[\[109\]](#cite_note-113)^{#cite_ref-113}

In addition to the national police and road police, Yerevan has its own municipal police. All three bodies cooperate to maintain law in the city.  

### Administrative districts {#Administrative_districts}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Yerevan-Map-Armenian-Labels.jpg/350px-Yerevan-Map-Armenian-Labels.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan-Map-Armenian-Labels.jpg) The twelve districts of Yerevan  
Main article: [Districts of Yerevan](/wiki/Districts_of_Yerevan "Districts of Yerevan")

Yerevan is divided into twelve "administrative districts" (վարչական շրջան, *varčakan šrĵan* )^[\[110\]](#cite_note-114)^ each with an elected leader. The total area of the 12 districts of Yerevan is 223 square kilometres (86 square miles).^[\[111\]](#cite_note-115)^^[\[112\]](#cite_note-116)^^[\[113\]](#cite_note-117)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-2022_Census-19)^{#cite_ref-2022_Census_19-2}

[Historical population]

Originally a small town, Yerevan became the capital of Armenia and a large city with over one million inhabitants.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Until the fall of the Soviet Union, the majority of the population of Yerevan were Armenians with minorities of [Russians](/wiki/Russians "Russians"), [Kurds](/wiki/Kurds "Kurds"), [Azerbaijanis](/wiki/Azerbaijanis "Azerbaijanis") and Iranians present as well. However, with the breakout of the [First Nagorno-Karabakh War](/wiki/First_Nagorno-Karabakh_War "First Nagorno-Karabakh War") from 1988 to 1994, the Azerbaijani minority diminished in the country in what was part of population exchanges between Armenia and Azerbaijan. A big part of the Russian minority also fled the country during the 1990s economic crisis in the country.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ Today, the population of Yerevan is overwhelmingly Armenian.

After the collapse of the Soviet Union, due to economic crises, thousands fled Armenia, mostly to Russia, North America and Europe. The population of Yerevan fell from 1,250,000 in 1989^[\[88\]](#cite_note-Azatian-92)^ to 1,103,488 in 2001^[\[130\]](#cite_note-135)^ and to 1,091,235 in 2003.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-ArmStat_2003-136)^ However, the population of Yerevan has been increasing since. In 2007, the capital had 1,107,800 inhabitants.{#cite_ref-ArmStat_2003_136-0}

Yerevantsis in general use the [Yerevan dialect](/wiki/Yerevan_dialect "Yerevan dialect"), an [Eastern Armenian](/wiki/Eastern_Armenian "Eastern Armenian") dialect most probably formed during the 13th century. It is currently spoken in and around Yerevan, including the towns of [Vagharshapat](/wiki/Vagharshapat "Vagharshapat") and [Ashtarak](/wiki/Ashtarak "Ashtarak"). [Classical Armenian](/wiki/Classical_Armenian "Classical Armenian") (*Grabar* ) words compose a significant part of the dialect's vocabulary.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-Markossian-137)^ Throughout the history, it was influenced by several languages, especially [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language") and [Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language") and [loan words](/wiki/Loan_word "Loan word") have significant presence in it today. It is currently the most widespread Armenian dialect.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-Baghdassarian-Tapaltsian-138)^{#cite_ref-Baghdassarian-Tapaltsian_138-0}  

### Ethnic groups {#Ethnic_groups}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/St._Nikolai.png/220px-St._Nikolai.png)](/wiki/File:St._Nikolai.png) [Saint Nikolai Russian Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Nikolai_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Nikolai Cathedral, Yerevan"), destroyed in 1931

Yerevan was inhabited first by Armenians and remained homogeneous until the 15th century.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-Karapetyan_1600-1724-118)^^[\[115\]](#cite_note-Karapetyan_1724-1800-119)^^[\[134\]](#cite_note-worldhistory-139)^^\[*[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")*\]^ The population of the [Erivan Fortress](/wiki/Erivan_Fortress "Erivan Fortress"), founded in the 1580s, was mainly composed of Muslim soldiers, estimated two to three thousand.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-Karapetyan_1600-1724-118)^ The city itself was mainly populated by Armenians. French traveler [Jean-Baptiste Tavernier](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Tavernier "Jean-Baptiste Tavernier"), who visited Yerevan possibly up to six times between 1631 and 1668, states that the city is exclusively populated by Armenians.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-Tavernier-140)^ Although much of the Armenian population of the city was deported during the 17th century,^[\[63\]](#cite_note-v8f5-67)^ the city remained Armenian-majority during the [Ottoman--Hotaki War (1722--1727)](/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Hotaki_War_(1722%E2%80%931727) "Ottoman–Hotaki War (1722–1727)").^[\[115\]](#cite_note-Karapetyan_1724-1800-119)^ The demographics of the region changed because of a series of wars between the Ottoman Empire, Iran and Russia. In the early 19th century Yerevan had a Muslim majority, mainly with an Armenian and "Caucasian Tatar" population.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBournoutian198013-141)^^[\[137\]](#cite_note-142)^ According to the traveler [H. F. B. Lynch](/wiki/H._F._B._Lynch "H. F. B. Lynch"), the city was about 50% Armenian and 50% Muslim ([Azerbaijanis](/wiki/Azerbaijani_people "Azerbaijani people") and Persians) in the early 1890s ^[\[138\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKettenhofenBournoutianHewsen1998542–551-143)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKettenhofenBournoutianHewsen1998542–551_143-0}

After the [Armenian genocide](/wiki/Armenian_genocide "Armenian genocide"), many refugees from what Armenians call [Western Armenia](/wiki/Western_Armenia "Western Armenia") (nowadays Turkey, then [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire")) escaped to Eastern Armenia. In 1919, about 75,000 Armenian refugees from the Ottoman Empire arrived in Yerevan, mostly from the [Vaspurakan](/wiki/Vaspurakan "Vaspurakan") region (city of [Van](/wiki/Van,_Turkey "Van, Turkey") and [surroundings](/wiki/Van_vilayet "Van vilayet")). A significant part of these refugees died of typhus and other diseases.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-144)^{#cite_ref-144}

From 1921 to 1936, about 42,000 ethnic Armenians from Iraq, Turkey, Iran, Greece, Syria, France, Bulgaria etc. went to Soviet Armenia, with most of them settling in Yerevan. The second wave of repatriation occurred from 1946 to 1948, when about 100,000 ethnic Armenians from Iran, Syria, Lebanon, Greece, Bulgaria, Romania, Cyprus, Palestine, Iraq, Egypt, France, United States etc. moved to Soviet Armenia, again most of whom settled in Yerevan. Thus, the ethnic makeup of Yerevan became more [monoethnic](/wiki/Monoethnicity "Monoethnicity") during the first 3 decades in the Soviet Union. The Azerbaijani population of Yerevan, who made up 43% of the population of the city prior to the [October Revolution](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution"), dropped to 0.7% by 1959 and further to 0.1% by 1989, during the [Nagorno-Karabakh conflict](/wiki/Nagorno-Karabakh_conflict "Nagorno-Karabakh conflict").^[\[140\]](#cite_note-145)^{#cite_ref-145}

There is an [Indian](/wiki/Indian_people "Indian people") population in Armenia, with over 22,000 residents recorded in the country. Much of this population resides in Yerevan, where a large proportion run businesses, Indian restaurants, and study in Yerevan universities.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-JamNews-146)^^[\[142\]](#cite_note-147)^{#cite_ref-147}  

### Religion {#Religion}

See also: [List of churches in Yerevan](/wiki/List_of_churches_in_Yerevan "List of churches in Yerevan") and [Religion in Armenia](/wiki/Religion_in_Armenia "Religion in Armenia")  

#### Armenian Apostolic Church {#Armenian_Apostolic_Church}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Saint_Peter_and_Paul_Church%2C_Yerevan.jpg/220px-Saint_Peter_and_Paul_Church%2C_Yerevan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Saint_Peter_and_Paul_Church,_Yerevan.jpg) The 5th-century [Saint Paul and Peter Church](/wiki/Saint_Paul_and_Peter_Church,_Yerevan "Saint Paul and Peter Church, Yerevan")

[Armenian Apostolic Christianity](/wiki/Armenian_Apostolic_Church "Armenian Apostolic Church") is the predominant religion in Armenia. The 5th-century [Saint Paul and Peter Church](/wiki/Saint_Paul_and_Peter_Church,_Yerevan "Saint Paul and Peter Church, Yerevan") demolished in November 1930 by the Soviets, was among the earliest churches ever built in Erebuni-Yerevan. Many of the ancient Armenian and medieval churches of the city were destroyed by the Soviets in the 1930s during the [Great Purge](/wiki/Great_Purge "Great Purge").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Surb_Hovanes_Mkrtich_Church%2C_Kond.JPG/220px-Surb_Hovanes_Mkrtich_Church%2C_Kond.JPG)](/wiki/File:Surb_Hovanes_Mkrtich_Church,_Kond.JPG) [Saint John the Baptist Church](/wiki/Saint_John_the_Baptist_Church,_Yerevan "Saint John the Baptist Church, Yerevan"), consecrated in 1710 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/St.Sarqis.jpg/220px-St.Sarqis.jpg)](/wiki/File:St.Sarqis.jpg) [Surp Sarkis](/wiki/Saint_Sarkis_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Sarkis Cathedral, Yerevan") Church, consecrated in 1842

The regulating body of the Armenian Church in Yerevan is the [Araratian Pontifical Diocese](/wiki/Araratian_Pontifical_Diocese "Araratian Pontifical Diocese"), with the [Surp Sarkis Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Sarkis_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Sarkis Cathedral, Yerevan") being the seat of the diocese. It is the largest diocese of the Armenian Church and one of the oldest dioceses in the world, covering the city of Yerevan and the [Ararat Province](/wiki/Ararat_Province "Ararat Province") of Armenia.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-araratian-tem1-33)^{#cite_ref-araratian-tem1_33-1}

Yerevan is currently home to the largest Armenian church in the world, the [Cathedral of Saint Gregory the Illuminator](/wiki/Saint_Gregory_the_Illuminator_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Gregory the Illuminator Cathedral, Yerevan"). It was consecrated in 2001, during the 1700th anniversary of the establishment of the Armenian Church and the adoption of Christianity as the national religion in Armenia.

As of 2017, Yerevan has 17 active Armenian churches as well as four chapels.  

#### Russian Orthodox Church {#Russian_Orthodox_Church}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%86%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8C_%D0%B2_%D0%95%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B5_%282%29.jpg/220px-%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%86%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8C_%D0%B2_%D0%95%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B5_%282%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%86%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%8C_%D0%B2_%D0%95%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B5_(2).jpg) Holy Cross Russian Orthodox Church, consecrated in 2017

After the capture of Yerevan by the Russians as a result of the [Russo-Persian War of 1826--28](/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1826%E2%80%931828) "Russo-Persian War (1826–1828)"), many [Russian Orthodox](/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church "Russian Orthodox Church") churches were built in the city under the orders of the Russian commander General [Ivan Paskevich](/wiki/Ivan_Paskevich "Ivan Paskevich"). The [Saint Nikolai Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Nikolai_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Nikolai Cathedral, Yerevan") opened during the second half of the 19th century, was the largest Russian church in the city. The [Church of the Intercession of the Holy Mother of God](/wiki/Church_of_the_Intercession_of_the_Holy_Mother_of_God "Church of the Intercession of the Holy Mother of God") was opened in 1916 in [Kanaker-Zeytun](/wiki/Kanaker-Zeytun_District "Kanaker-Zeytun District").^[\[143\]](#cite_note-148)^{#cite_ref-148}

However, most of the churches were either closed or demolished by the Soviets during the 1930s. The Saint Nikolai Cathedral was entirely destroyed in 1931, while the Church of the Intercession of the Holy Mother of God was closed and converted first into a warehouse and later into a club for the military personnel. Religious services resumed in the church in 1991, and in 2004 a cupola and a belfry were added to the building.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-149)^ In 2010, the groundbreaking ceremony of the new Holy Cross Russian Orthodox church took place with the presence of Patriarch [Kirill I of Moscow](/wiki/Kirill_I_of_Moscow "Kirill I of Moscow"). The church was eventually consecrated on 7 October 2017, with the presence of Catholicos [Karekin II](/wiki/Karekin_II "Karekin II"), Russian bishops and the church benefactor [Ara Abramyan](/wiki/Ara_Abramyan "Ara Abramyan").{#cite_ref-149}  

#### Other religions {#Other_religions}

According to Ivan Chopin, there were eight mosques in Yerevan in the middle of the 19th century.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-150)^^[\[146\]](#cite_note-151)^ The 18th-century [Blue Mosque of Yerevan](/wiki/Blue_Mosque,_Yerevan "Blue Mosque, Yerevan") was restored and reopened in the 1990s, with Iranian funding,^[\[147\]](#cite_note-152)^ and is currently the only active mosque in Armenia, mainly serving Iranian [Shia](/wiki/Shia "Shia") visitors.{#cite_ref-152}

Yerevan is home to tiny [Yezidi](/wiki/Yazidis_in_Armenia "Yazidis in Armenia"), [Molokan](/wiki/Molokan "Molokan"), [Neopagan](/wiki/Hetanism "Hetanism"), [Baháʼí](/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith "Baháʼí Faith") and [Jewish](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Armenia "History of the Jews in Armenia") communities, with the Jewish community being represented by the Jewish Council of Armenia. A variety of [nontrinitarian](/wiki/Nontrinitarianism "Nontrinitarianism") communities, considered dangerous sects by the Armenian Apostolic Church,^[\[148\]](#cite_note-153)^ are also found in the city, including [Jehovah's Witnesses](/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses "Jehovah's Witnesses"), [Mormons](/wiki/Mormons "Mormons"), [Seventh-day Adventists](/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church "Seventh-day Adventist Church") and [Word of Life](/wiki/Livets_Ord "Livets Ord").^[\[149\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}  

Health and medical care {#Health_and_medical_care}
--------------------------------------------------

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Shengavit_Medical_Center_-_%D5%87%D5%A5%D5%B6%D5%A3%D5%A1%D5%BE%D5%AB%D5%A9_%D5%A2%D5%AA%D5%B7%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%AF%D5%A5%D5%B6%D5%BF%D6%80%D5%B8%D5%B6.jpg/220px-Shengavit_Medical_Center_-_%D5%87%D5%A5%D5%B6%D5%A3%D5%A1%D5%BE%D5%AB%D5%A9_%D5%A2%D5%AA%D5%B7%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%AF%D5%A5%D5%B6%D5%BF%D6%80%D5%B8%D5%B6.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shengavit_Medical_Center_-_%D5%87%D5%A5%D5%B6%D5%A3%D5%A1%D5%BE%D5%AB%D5%A9_%D5%A2%D5%AA%D5%B7%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%AF%D5%A5%D5%B6%D5%BF%D6%80%D5%B8%D5%B6.jpg) [Shengavit Medical Center](/wiki/Shengavit_Medical_Center "Shengavit Medical Center")

Yerevan is a major healthcare and medical service centre in the region. Several hospitals of Yerevan, refurbished with modern technologies, provide healthcare and conduct medical research, such as [Shengavit Medical Center](/wiki/Shengavit_Medical_Center "Shengavit Medical Center"), Erebouni Medical Center, [Izmirlian Medical Center](/wiki/Izmirlian_Medical_Center "Izmirlian Medical Center"), Saint Gregory the Illuminator Medical Center, [Nork-Marash Medical Center](/wiki/Nork-Marash_Medical_Center "Nork-Marash Medical Center"), Armenia Republican Medical Center, Astghik Medical Center, [Armenian American Wellness Center](/wiki/Armenian_American_Wellness_Center "Armenian American Wellness Center"), and Mkhitar Heratsi Hospital Complex of the [Yerevan State Medical University](/wiki/Yerevan_State_Medical_University "Yerevan State Medical University"). The municipality runs 39 polyclinics/medical centers throughout the city.

The Research Center of Maternal and Child Health Protection has operated in Yerevan since 1937, while the [Armenicum Clinical Center](/wiki/Armenicum "Armenicum") was opened in 1999,^[\[150\]](#cite_note-155)^ where research is conducted mainly related to infectious diseases, including [HIV](/wiki/HIV "HIV"), [immunodeficiency disorders](/wiki/Immunodeficiency "Immunodeficiency") and [hepatitis](/wiki/Hepatitis "Hepatitis").{#cite_ref-155}

The Liqvor Pharmaceuticals Factory, operating in Yerevan since 1991, is currently the largest medicine manufacturer of Armenia.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-156)^{#cite_ref-156}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

Yerevan is Armenia's principal cultural, artistic, and industrial center, with a large number of museums, important monuments and the national public library. It also hosts [Vardavar](/wiki/Vardavar "Vardavar"), the most widely celebrated festival among Armenians, and is one of the historic centres of traditional [Armenian carpet weaving](/wiki/Armenian_carpet "Armenian carpet").  

### Museums {#Museums}

See also: [List of museums in Yerevan](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Yerevan "List of museums in Yerevan")

Yerevan is home to a large number of museums, art galleries and libraries. The most prominent of these are the [National Gallery of Armenia](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Armenia "National Gallery of Armenia"), the [History Museum of Armenia](/wiki/History_Museum_of_Armenia "History Museum of Armenia"), the [Cafesjian Museum of Art](/wiki/Cafesjian_Museum_of_Art "Cafesjian Museum of Art"), the [Matenadaran](/wiki/Matenadaran "Matenadaran") library of ancient manuscripts, and the Armenian Genocide Museum at the [Tsitsernakaberd](/wiki/Tsitsernakaberd "Tsitsernakaberd") Armenian Genocide Memorial Complex.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Armenia_Museum_of_Art_and_History.jpg/220px-Armenia_Museum_of_Art_and_History.jpg)](/wiki/File:Armenia_Museum_of_Art_and_History.jpg) The National Gallery of Armenia

Founded in 1921, the [National Gallery of Armenia](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Armenia "National Gallery of Armenia") and the [History Museum of Armenia](/wiki/History_Museum_of_Armenia "History Museum of Armenia") are the principal museums of the city. In addition to having a permanent exposition of works by Armenian painters, the gallery houses a collection of paintings, drawings and sculptures by German, American, Austrian, Belgian, Spanish, French, Hungarian, Italian, Dutch, Russian and Swiss artists.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-157)^ It usually hosts temporary expositions.{#cite_ref-157}

The Armenian Genocide Museum is located at the foot of the Tsitsernakaberd Armenian Genocide Memorial Complex and features numerous eyewitness accounts, texts and photographs from the time. It comprises a memorial stone made of three parts, the latter of which is dedicated to the intellectual and political figures who, as the museum's site says, "raised their protest against the Genocide committed against the Armenians by the Turks," such as [Armin T. Wegner](/wiki/Armin_T._Wegner "Armin T. Wegner"), [Hedvig Büll](/wiki/Anna_Hedvig_B%C3%BCll "Anna Hedvig Büll"), [Henry Morgenthau Sr.](/wiki/Henry_Morgenthau_Sr. "Henry Morgenthau Sr."), [Franz Werfel](/wiki/Franz_Werfel "Franz Werfel"), [Johannes Lepsius](/wiki/Johannes_Lepsius "Johannes Lepsius"), [James Bryce](/wiki/James_Bryce,_1st_Viscount_Bryce "James Bryce, 1st Viscount Bryce"), [Anatole France](/wiki/Anatole_France "Anatole France"), [Giacomo Gorrini](/wiki/Giacomo_Gorrini "Giacomo Gorrini"), [Benedict XV](/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XV "Pope Benedict XV"), [Fridtjof Nansen](/wiki/Fridtjof_Nansen "Fridtjof Nansen"), and others.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/View_of_Yerevan_and_Mount_Ararat_from_Cafesjian_Museum_of_Art.JPG/220px-View_of_Yerevan_and_Mount_Ararat_from_Cafesjian_Museum_of_Art.JPG)](/wiki/File:View_of_Yerevan_and_Mount_Ararat_from_Cafesjian_Museum_of_Art.JPG) View from a garden terrace of the Cafesjian Museum of Art at [the Cascade](/wiki/Yerevan_Cascade "Yerevan Cascade")

[Cafesjian Museum of Art](/wiki/Cafesjian_Museum_of_Art "Cafesjian Museum of Art") within the [Yerevan Cascade](/wiki/Yerevan_Cascade "Yerevan Cascade") is an art centre opened on 7 November 2009. It showcases a massive collection of glass artwork, particularly the works of the Czech artists [Stanislav Libenský and Jaroslava Brychtová](/wiki/Stanislav_Libensk%C3%BD_and_Jaroslava_Brychtov%C3%A1 "Stanislav Libenský and Jaroslava Brychtová"). The front gardens showcase sculptures from Gerard L. Cafesjian's collection.

The [Erebuni Museum](/wiki/Erebuni_Museum "Erebuni Museum") founded in 1968, is an archaeological museum housing [Urartian](/wiki/Urartu "Urartu") artifacts found during excavations at the [Erebuni Fortress](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress"). The [Yerevan History Museum](/wiki/Yerevan_History_Museum "Yerevan History Museum") and the [Armenian Revolutionary Federation History Museum](/wiki/ARF_History_Museum "ARF History Museum") are among the prominent museums that feature the history of Yerevan and the First Republic of Armenia respectively. The Military Museum within the [Mother Armenia](/wiki/Mother_Armenia "Mother Armenia") complex is about the participation of Armenian soldiers in [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and the [Nagorno-Karabakh conflict](/wiki/Nagorno-Karabakh_conflict "Nagorno-Karabakh conflict").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B0_1.jpg/220px-%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B0_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D1%83%D0%B7%D0%B5%D0%B9_%D0%9A%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%B8%D1%82%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B0_1.jpg) Komitas Museum

The city is also home to a large number of art museums. [Sergei Parajanov Museum](/wiki/Sergei_Parajanov_Museum "Sergei Parajanov Museum") opened in 1988 is dedicated to [Sergei Parajanov](/wiki/Sergei_Parajanov "Sergei Parajanov")'s art works in cinema and painting.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-158)^ [Komitas Museum](/wiki/Komitas_Museum "Komitas Museum") opened in 2015, is a musical art museum devoted to the renowned Armenian composer [Komitas](/wiki/Komitas "Komitas"). [Charents Museum of Literature and Arts](/wiki/Charents_Museum_of_Literature_and_Arts "Charents Museum of Literature and Arts") opened in 1921, [Modern Art Museum of Yerevan](/wiki/Modern_Art_Museum_of_Yerevan "Modern Art Museum of Yerevan") opened in 1972, and the [Middle East Art Museum](/wiki/Near_East_Art_Museum "Near East Art Museum") opened in 1993, are also among the notable art museums of the city.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}

Biographical museums are also common in Yerevan. Many renowned Armenian poets, painters and musicians are honored with house-museums in their memory, such as poet [Hovhannes Tumanyan](/wiki/Hovhannes_Tumanyan "Hovhannes Tumanyan"), composer [Aram Khachaturian](/wiki/Aram_Khachaturian "Aram Khachaturian"), painter [Martiros Saryan](/wiki/Martiros_Saryan "Martiros Saryan"), novelist [Khachatur Abovian](/wiki/Khachatur_Abovian "Khachatur Abovian"), and French-Armenian singer [Charles Aznavour](/wiki/Charles_Aznavour "Charles Aznavour").

Many museums of science and technology have opened in Yerevan, such as the Museum of Armenian Medicine (1999), the Space Museum of Yerevan (2001), Museum of Science and Technology (2008), Museum of Communications (2012) and the Little Einstein Interactive Science Museum (2016).  

### Libraries {#Libraries}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Matenadaran%2C_Erev%C3%A1n%2C_Armenia%2C_2016-10-03%2C_DD_22.jpg/220px-Matenadaran%2C_Erev%C3%A1n%2C_Armenia%2C_2016-10-03%2C_DD_22.jpg)](/wiki/File:Matenadaran,_Erev%C3%A1n,_Armenia,_2016-10-03,_DD_22.jpg) Matenadaran library-museum of ancient manuscripts

The [National Library of Armenia](/wiki/National_Library_of_Armenia "National Library of Armenia") located on Teryan Street is the chief public library of the city and the entire republic. It was founded in 1832 and is operating in its current building since 1939. Another national library of Yerevan is the [Khnko Aper Children's Library](/wiki/Khnko_Aper_Children%27s_Library "Khnko Aper Children's Library"), founded in 1933. Other major public libraries include the [Avetik Isahakyan Central Library](/wiki/City_Central_Library_after_Avetik_Isahakyan "City Central Library after Avetik Isahakyan") founded in 1935, the Republican Library of Medical Sciences founded in 1939, the Library of Science and Technology founded in 1957, and the Musical Library founded in 1965. In addition, each administrative district of Yerevan has its own public library (usually more than one library).

The [Matenadaran](/wiki/Matenadaran "Matenadaran") is a library-museum and a research centre, regrouping 17,000 ancient manuscripts and several bibles from the Middle Ages. Its archives hold a rich collection of valuable ancient [Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language"), [Ancient Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek"), [Aramaic](/wiki/Aramaic_language "Aramaic language"), [Assyrian](/wiki/Assyrian_Neo-Aramaic "Assyrian Neo-Aramaic"), [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"), [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin"), [Middle](/wiki/Middle_Persian "Middle Persian") and [Modern Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language") manuscripts. It is located on [Mashtots Avenue](/wiki/Mashtots_Avenue "Mashtots Avenue") at central Yerevan.

On 6 June 2010, Yerevan was named as the 2012 [World Book Capital](/wiki/World_Book_Capital "World Book Capital") by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization ([UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO")). The Armenian capital was chosen for the quality and variety of the programme it presented to the selection committee, which met at UNESCO's headquarters in Paris on 2 July 2010.

The [National Archives of Armenia](/wiki/National_Archives_of_Armenia "National Archives of Armenia") founded in 1923, is a scientific research centre and depositary, with a collection of around 3.5 million units of valuable documents.  

### Art {#Art}

Main article: [Armenian art](/wiki/Armenian_art "Armenian art")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Yerevan_Vernissage_carpets.jpg/220px-Yerevan_Vernissage_carpets.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_Vernissage_carpets.jpg) Handmade Armenian rugs at the Yerevan Vernissage

Yerevan is one of the historic centres of traditional [Armenian carpet](/wiki/Armenian_carpet "Armenian carpet"). Various rug fragments have been excavated in areas around Yerevan dating back to the 7th century BC or earlier. The tradition was further developed from the 16th century when Yerevan became the central city of [Persian Armenia](/wiki/Persian_Armenia_(1502-1828) "Persian Armenia (1502-1828)"). However, carpet manufacturing in the city was greatly enriched with the flock of Western Armenian migrants from the [Ottoman Empire](/wiki/Ottoman_Empire "Ottoman Empire") throughout the 19th century, and the arrival of Armenian refugees escaping the genocide in the early 20th century. Currently, the city is home to the Arm Carpet factory opened in 1924, as well as the Tufenkian handmade carpets (since 1994), and Megerian handmade carpets (since 2000).
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Yerevan_-_July_2017_-_various_topics_-_4.JPG/220px-Yerevan_-_July_2017_-_various_topics_-_4.JPG)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_-_July_2017_-_various_topics_-_4.JPG) Paintings exhibited at Saryan Park

The [Yerevan Vernissage](/wiki/Yerevan_Vernissage "Yerevan Vernissage") open-air exhibition-market formed in the late 1980s on [Aram Street](/wiki/Aram_Street "Aram Street"), features a large collection of different types of traditional Armenian hand-made art works, especially woodwork sculptures, rugs and carpets. On the other hand, the Saryan park located near the opera house, is famous for being a permanent venue where artists exhibit their paintings.

The [Armenian Center for Contemporary Experimental Art](/wiki/Armenian_Center_for_Contemporary_Experimental_Art "Armenian Center for Contemporary Experimental Art") founded in 1992 in Yerevan,^[\[155\]](#cite_note-160)^ is a creativity centre helping to exchange experience between professional artists in an appropriate atmosphere.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-161)^{#cite_ref-161}  

#### Music {#Music}

Main article: [Music of Armenia](/wiki/Music_of_Armenia "Music of Armenia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/%C3%93pera%2C_Erev%C3%A1n%2C_Armenia%2C_2016-10-03%2C_DD_12.jpg/220px-%C3%93pera%2C_Erev%C3%A1n%2C_Armenia%2C_2016-10-03%2C_DD_12.jpg)](/wiki/File:%C3%93pera,_Erev%C3%A1n,_Armenia,_2016-10-03,_DD_12.jpg) [Yerevan Opera Theater](/wiki/Yerevan_Opera_Theater "Yerevan Opera Theater")

[Jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz"), [classical](/wiki/Classical_music "Classical music"), [folk](/wiki/Armenian_folk_music "Armenian folk music") and traditional music are among several genres that are popular in the city of Yerevan. A large number of ensembles, orchestras and choirs of different types of Armenian and international music are active in the city.

The [Armenian Philharmonic Orchestra](/wiki/Armenian_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Armenian Philharmonic Orchestra") founded in 1925, is one of the oldest musical groups in Yerevan and modern Armenia. The [Armenian National Radio Chamber Choir](/wiki/Armenian_National_Radio_Chamber_Choir "Armenian National Radio Chamber Choir") founded in 1929, won the First Prize of the Soviet Union in the 1931 competition of choirs among the [republics of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Republics_of_the_Soviet_Union "Republics of the Soviet Union"). Folk and classical music of Armenia was taught in state-sponsored conservatoires during the Soviet days. The Sayat-Nova Armenian Folk Song Ensemble was founded in Yerevan in 1938. Currently directed by Tovmas Poghosyan, the ensemble performs the works of prominent Armenian *[gusans](/wiki/Gusans "Gusans")* such as [Sayat-Nova](/wiki/Sayat-Nova "Sayat-Nova"), [Jivani](/wiki/Jivani "Jivani"), and [Sheram](/wiki/Sheram "Sheram").

In 1939, the [Armenian National Academic Theatre of Opera and Ballet](/wiki/Yerevan_Opera_Theater "Yerevan Opera Theater") was opened. It is home to the Aram Khatchaturian concert hall and the Alexander Spendiarian auditorium of the National Theatre of Opera and Ballet.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/%D5%80%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A4%D5%AB%D5%BD%D5%A1%D5%BF%D5%A5%D5%BD%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%AB%D5%B6_%D5%B7%D5%A5%D5%B6%D6%84._%D4%BF%D5%B8%D5%B4%D5%AB%D5%BF%D5%A1%D5%BD%D5%AB_%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D4%BF%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A5%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%AB%D5%B6_%D4%B5%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%AA%D5%B7%D5%BF%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%BF%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B6%D5%A8_%283%29.JPG/220px-%D5%80%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A4%D5%AB%D5%BD%D5%A1%D5%BF%D5%A5%D5%BD%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%AB%D5%B6_%D5%B7%D5%A5%D5%B6%D6%84._%D4%BF%D5%B8%D5%B4%D5%AB%D5%BF%D5%A1%D5%BD%D5%AB_%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D4%BF%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A5%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%AB%D5%B6_%D4%B5%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%AA%D5%B7%D5%BF%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%BF%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B6%D5%A8_%283%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:%D5%80%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A4%D5%AB%D5%BD%D5%A1%D5%BF%D5%A5%D5%BD%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%AB%D5%B6_%D5%B7%D5%A5%D5%B6%D6%84._%D4%BF%D5%B8%D5%B4%D5%AB%D5%BF%D5%A1%D5%BD%D5%AB_%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D4%BF%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A5%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%AB%D5%B6_%D4%B5%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%AA%D5%B7%D5%BF%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%BF%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B6%D5%A8_(3).JPG) Komitas Chamber Music House

The [Komitas Chamber Music House](/wiki/Komitas_Chamber_Music_House "Komitas Chamber Music House") opened in 1977, is the home of [chamber music](/wiki/Chamber_music "Chamber music") performers and lovers in Armenia. In 1983, the [Karen Demirchyan Sports and Concerts Complex](/wiki/Karen_Demirchyan_Complex "Karen Demirchyan Complex") was opened. It is currently the largest indoor venue in Armenia.

The [National Chamber Orchestra of Armenia](/wiki/National_Chamber_Orchestra_of_Armenia "National Chamber Orchestra of Armenia") (founded in 1961), Yerevan State Brass Band (1964), Folk Instruments Orchestra of Armenia (1977), Gusan and Folk Song Ensemble of Armenia (1983), [Hover Chamber Choir](/wiki/Hover_Chamber_Choir "Hover Chamber Choir") (1992), [Shoghaken Folk Ensemble](/wiki/Shoghaken_Folk_Ensemble "Shoghaken Folk Ensemble") (1995), Yerevan State Chamber Choir (1996), State Orchestra of Armenian National Instruments (2004), and the Youth State Orchestra of Armenia (2005), are also among the famous musical ensembles of the city of Yerevan. The [Ars lunga](/wiki/Ars_lunga "Ars lunga") [piano](/wiki/Piano "Piano")-[cello](/wiki/Cello "Cello") duo achieved international fame since its foundation in 2009 in Yerevan.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

Armenian religious music remained liturgical until [Komitas](/wiki/Komitas "Komitas") introduced [polyphony](/wiki/Polyphony "Polyphony") by the end of the 19th century. Starting from the late 1950s, religious music became widely spread when [Armenian chants](/wiki/Armenian_chant "Armenian chant") (also known as *sharakans* ) were performed by the [soprano](/wiki/Soprano "Soprano") [Lusine Zakaryan](/wiki/Lusine_Zakaryan "Lusine Zakaryan").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^The state-run Tagharan Ensemble of Yerevan founded in 1981 and currently directed by Sedrak Yerkanian, also performs ritual and ancient Armenian music.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

[Jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") is also among the popular genres in Yerevan. The first [jazz band in Yerevan](/wiki/Jazz_in_Armenia "Jazz in Armenia") was founded in 1936. Currently, many jazz and [ethno jazz](/wiki/Ethno_jazz "Ethno jazz") bands are active in Yerevan such as Time Report, Art Voices, and [Nuance Jazz Band](/wiki/Nuance_Jazz_Band "Nuance Jazz Band"). The Malkhas jazz club founded by renowned artist Levon Malkhasian, is among the most popular clubs in the city. The Yerevan Jazz Fest is an annual jazz festival taking place every autumn since 2015, organized by the Armenian Jazz Association with the support of the Yerevan Municipality.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-162)^{#cite_ref-162}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/KOHAR_with_stars_of_Armenia-Yerevan-May_2011.jpg/220px-KOHAR_with_stars_of_Armenia-Yerevan-May_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:KOHAR_with_stars_of_Armenia-Yerevan-May_2011.jpg) KOHAR performing at the Freedom Square in 2011

[Armenian rock](/wiki/Armenian_rock "Armenian rock") has been originated in Yerevan in the mid-1960s, mainly through [Arthur Meschian](/wiki/Arthur_Meschian "Arthur Meschian") and his band *Arakyalner* *(Disciples)* . In the early 1970s, there were a range of professional bands in Yerevan strong enough to compete with their Soviet counterparts. In post-Soviet Armenia, an Armenian progressive rock scene has been developed in Yerevan, mainly through [Vahan Artsruni](/wiki/Vahan_Artsruni "Vahan Artsruni"), the [Oaksenham](/wiki/Oaksenham "Oaksenham") rock band, and the [Dorians](/wiki/Dorians_(band) "Dorians (band)") band. The [Armenian Navy Band](/wiki/Arto_Tun%C3%A7boyac%C4%B1yan#Armenian_Navy_Band "Arto Tunçboyacıyan") founded by [Arto Tunçboyacıyan](/wiki/Arto_Tun%C3%A7boyac%C4%B1yan "Arto Tunçboyacıyan") in 1998 is also famous for jazz, [avant-garde](/wiki/Avant-garde_music "Avant-garde music") and folk music. [Reggae](/wiki/Reggae "Reggae") is also becoming popular in Yerevan mainly through the [Reincarnation](/wiki/Reincarnation_(band) "Reincarnation (band)") musical band.

The Cafesjian Center for the Arts is known for its regularly programmed events including the "Cafesjian Classical Music Series" on the first Wednesday of each month, and the "Music Cascade" series of jazz, pop and rock music live concerts performed every Friday and Saturday.

Open-air concerts are frequently held in curtain location in Yerevan during summer, such as the Cafesjian Sculpture Garden on Tamanyan Street, the [Freedom Square](/wiki/Freedom_Square,_Yerevan "Freedom Square, Yerevan") near the Opera House, the Republic Square, etc. The famous [KOHAR Symphony Orchestra and Choir](/wiki/KOHAR_Symphony_Orchestra_and_Choir "KOHAR Symphony Orchestra and Choir") occasionally performs open-air concerts in the city.  

#### Dance {#Dance}

[Traditional dancing](/wiki/Armenian_dance "Armenian dance") is very popular among Armenians. During the cool summertime of the Yerevan city, it is very common to find people dancing in groups at the Northern Avenue or the [Tamanyan Street](/wiki/Tamanyan_Street "Tamanyan Street") near the cascade.

Professional dance groups were formed in Yerevan during the Soviet days. The first group was the Armenian Folk Music and Dance Ensemble founded in 1938 by [Tatul Altunyan](/wiki/Tatul_Altunyan "Tatul Altunyan"). It was followed by the State Dance Ensemble of Armenia in 1958. In 1963, the Berd Dance Ensemble was formed. The Barekamutyun State Dance Ensemble of Armenia was founded in 1987 by Norayr Mehrabyan.

The Karin Traditional Song and Dance Ensemble founded in 2001 by Gagik Ginosyan is known for revitalizing and performing the ancient Armenian dances of the historical regions of the [Armenian Highlands](/wiki/Armenian_Highlands "Armenian Highlands"),^[\[158\]](#cite_note-163)^ such as [Hamshen](/wiki/Hem%C5%9Fin "Hemşin"), [Mush](/wiki/Mu%C5%9F "Muş"), [Sasun](/wiki/Sason "Sason"), [Karin](/wiki/Erzurum "Erzurum"), etc.{#cite_ref-163}  

#### Theatre {#Theatre}

See also: [List of theaters in Yerevan](/wiki/List_of_theaters_in_Yerevan "List of theaters in Yerevan")

Yerevan is home to many theatre groups, mainly operating under the support of the ministry of culture. Theatre halls in the city organize several shows and performances throughout the year. Most prominent state-run theatres of Yerevan are the [Sundukyan State Academic Theatre](/wiki/Sundukyan_State_Academic_Theatre "Sundukyan State Academic Theatre"), [Paronyan Musical Comedy Theatre](/wiki/Paronyan_Musical_Comedy_Theatre "Paronyan Musical Comedy Theatre"), [Stanislavski Russian Theatre](/wiki/Stanislavski_Russian_Theatre_of_Yerevan "Stanislavski Russian Theatre of Yerevan"), [Hrachya Ghaplanyan Drama Theatre](/wiki/Hrachya_Ghaplanyan_Drama_Theatre "Hrachya Ghaplanyan Drama Theatre"), and the Sos Sargsyan Hamazgayin State Theatre. The Edgar Elbakyan Theatre of Drama and Comedy is among the prominent theatres run by the private sector.

Yerevan is also home to several specialized theatres such as the [Tumanyan Puppet Theatre](/wiki/Hovhannes_Tumanyan_Puppet_Theatre_of_Yerevan "Hovhannes Tumanyan Puppet Theatre of Yerevan"), [Yerevan State Pantomime Theatre](/wiki/Yerevan_State_Pantomime_Theatre "Yerevan State Pantomime Theatre"), and the [Yerevan State Marionettes Theatre](/wiki/Yerevan_State_Marionettes_Theatre "Yerevan State Marionettes Theatre").  

#### Cinema {#Cinema}

Main article: [Cinema of Armenia](/wiki/Cinema_of_Armenia "Cinema of Armenia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Moscow_cinema_in_Yerevan.jpg/220px-Moscow_cinema_in_Yerevan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Moscow_cinema_in_Yerevan.jpg) Moscow Cinema

Cinema in Armenia was born on 16 April 1923, when the Armenian State Committee of Cinema was established upon a decree issued by the Soviet Armenian government.

In March 1924, the first Armenian film studio; *[Armenfilm](/wiki/Armenfilm "Armenfilm")* ([Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language"): Հայֆիլմ "Hayfilm", [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): Арменкино "Armenkino") was opened in Yerevan, starting with a [documentary film](/wiki/Documentary_film "Documentary film") called *Soviet Armenia* . *[Namus](/wiki/Namus_(film) "Namus (film)")* was the first Armenian [silent](/wiki/Silent_film "Silent film") [black and white](/wiki/Black_and_white "Black and white") film, directed by [Hamo Beknazarian](/wiki/Hamo_Beknazarian "Hamo Beknazarian") in 1925, based on a play of [Alexander Shirvanzade](/wiki/Alexander_Shirvanzade "Alexander Shirvanzade"), describing the ill fate of two lovers, who were engaged by their families to each other since childhood, but because of violations of *[namus](/wiki/Namus "Namus")* (a tradition of honor), the girl was married by her father to another person. The first produced [sound film](/wiki/Sound_film "Sound film") was *[Pepo](/wiki/Pepo_(film) "Pepo (film)")* directed by [Hamo Beknazarian](/wiki/Hamo_Beknazarian "Hamo Beknazarian") in 1935.

Yerevan is home to many movie theatres including the [Moscow Cinema](/wiki/Moscow_Cinema "Moscow Cinema"), [Nairi Cinema](/wiki/Nairi_Cinema "Nairi Cinema"), Hayastan Cinema, Cinema Star multiplex cinemas of the [Dalma Garden Mall](/wiki/Dalma_Garden_Mall "Dalma Garden Mall"), and the KinoPark multiplex cinemas of [Yerevan Mall](/wiki/Yerevan_Mall "Yerevan Mall"). The city also hosts a number of film festivals:

* The [Golden Apricot Yerevan International Film Festival](/wiki/Golden_Apricot_Yerevan_International_Film_Festival "Golden Apricot Yerevan International Film Festival") has been hosted by the Moscow Cinema annually since 2004.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-164)^{#cite_ref-164}
* The ReAnimania International Animation Film \& Comics Art Festival of Yerevan launched in 2005, is also among the popular annual events in the city.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-165)^{#cite_ref-165}
* The [Sose International Film Festival](/w/index.php?title=Sose_International_Film_Festival&action=edit&redlink=1 "Sose International Film Festival (page does not exist)") has been held annually by the Zis Center of Culture since 2014.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-166)^{#cite_ref-166}

### Festivals {#Festivals}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Vartavar_2014_Yerevan_%285%29.jpg/220px-Vartavar_2014_Yerevan_%285%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vartavar_2014_Yerevan_(5).jpg) People celebrating Vardavar water festival in downtown Yerevan

In addition to the film and other arts festivals, the city organizes many public celebrations that greatly attract the locals as well as the visitors. [Vardavar](/wiki/Vardavar "Vardavar") is the most widely celebrated festival among Armenians, having it roots back to the pagan history of Armenia. It is celebrated 98 days (14 weeks) after [Easter](/wiki/Easter "Easter"). During the day of Vardavar, people from a wide array of ages are allowed to douse strangers with water. It is common to see people pouring buckets of water from balconies on unsuspecting people walking below them. The Swan Lake of the Yerevan Opera is the most popular venue for the Vardavar celebrations.

In August 2015, Teryan Cultural Centre supported by the Yerevan Municipality has launched its first Armenian traditional clothing festival known as the *Yerevan Taraz Fest* .^[\[162\]](#cite_note-167)^{#cite_ref-167}

As one of the ancient [winemaking](/wiki/Winemaking "Winemaking") regions, many wine festivals are celebrated in Armenia. Yerevan launched its first annual wine festivals known as the *[Yerevan Wine Days](/wiki/Yerevan_Wine_Days "Yerevan Wine Days")* in May 2016.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-168)^ The *Watermelon Fest* launched in 2013 is also becoming a popular event in the city. The *Yerevan Beer Fest* is held annually during the month of August. It was first organized in 2014.^[\[164\]](#cite_note-169)^{#cite_ref-169}  

### Media {#Media}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Yerevan_from_Cascade_-_panoramio.jpg/220px-Yerevan_from_Cascade_-_panoramio.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_from_Cascade_-_panoramio.jpg) [Yerevan TV Tower](/wiki/Yerevan_TV_Tower "Yerevan TV Tower")

Many public and private TV and radio channels operate in Yerevan. The [Public TV of Armenia](/wiki/Public_Television_company_of_Armenia "Public Television company of Armenia") has been in service since 1956. It became a [satellite television](/wiki/Satellite_television "Satellite television") in 1996. Other satellite TVs include the [Armenia TV](/wiki/Armenia_TV "Armenia TV") owned by the Pan-Armenian Media Group, [Kentron TV](/wiki/Kentron_TV "Kentron TV") owned by [Gagik Tsarukyan](/wiki/Gagik_Tsarukyan "Gagik Tsarukyan"), [Shant TV](/wiki/Shant_TV "Shant TV") and Shant TV premium. On the other hand, [Yerkir Media](/wiki/Yerkir_Media "Yerkir Media"), Armenia 2, [Shoghakat TV](/wiki/Shoghakat_TV "Shoghakat TV"), Yerevan TV, 21TV and the TV channels of the Pan-Armenian Media Group are among the most notable local televisions of Yerevan.

Notable newspapers published in Yerevan include the daily newspapers of [Aravot](/wiki/Aravot "Aravot"), [Azg](/wiki/Azg_(daily) "Azg (daily)"), [Golos Armenii](/wiki/Golos_Armenii "Golos Armenii") and [Hayastani Hanrapetutyun](/wiki/Hayastani_Hanrapetutyun "Hayastani Hanrapetutyun").  

### Monuments {#Monuments}

Main articles: [Monuments of Yerevan](/wiki/Monuments_of_Yerevan "Monuments of Yerevan") and [List of statues in Yerevan](/wiki/List_of_statues_in_Yerevan "List of statues in Yerevan")  

#### Historic {#Historic}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/-%D4%B5%D5%AF%D5%A5%D5%B2%D5%A5%D6%81%D5%A1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A1%D5%AC%D5%AB%D6%80_%D4%B1%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%AB_%D5%8D%D5%A2._%D4%B1%D5%BD%D5%BF%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%AE%D5%A1%D5%AE%D5%AB%D5%B6_%28%D4%BF%D5%A1%D5%A9%D5%B8%D5%B2%D5%AB%D5%AF%D5%A5%2C_%D4%BE%D5%AB%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A1%D5%BE%D5%B8%D6%80%29_23.jpg/220px--%D4%B5%D5%AF%D5%A5%D5%B2%D5%A5%D6%81%D5%A1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A1%D5%AC%D5%AB%D6%80_%D4%B1%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%AB_%D5%8D%D5%A2._%D4%B1%D5%BD%D5%BF%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%AE%D5%A1%D5%AE%D5%AB%D5%B6_%28%D4%BF%D5%A1%D5%A9%D5%B8%D5%B2%D5%AB%D5%AF%D5%A5%2C_%D4%BE%D5%AB%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A1%D5%BE%D5%B8%D6%80%29_23.jpg)](/wiki/File:-%D4%B5%D5%AF%D5%A5%D5%B2%D5%A5%D6%81%D5%A1%D5%AF%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B4%D5%A1%D5%AC%D5%AB%D6%80_%D4%B1%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%AB_%D5%8D%D5%A2._%D4%B1%D5%BD%D5%BF%D5%BE%D5%A1%D5%AE%D5%A1%D5%AE%D5%AB%D5%B6_(%D4%BF%D5%A1%D5%A9%D5%B8%D5%B2%D5%AB%D5%AF%D5%A5,_%D4%BE%D5%AB%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A1%D5%BE%D5%B8%D6%80)_23.jpg) [Cathedral of Avan](/wiki/Cathedral_of_Avan "Cathedral of Avan") built in 591 [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Erevan_church.jpg/220px-Erevan_church.jpg)](/wiki/File:Erevan_church.jpg) [Katoghike Church](/wiki/Katoghike_Church,_Yerevan "Katoghike Church, Yerevan") in Yerevan [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/St_Zoravor_church_in_Yerevan_01.JPG/220px-St_Zoravor_church_in_Yerevan_01.JPG)](/wiki/File:St_Zoravor_church_in_Yerevan_01.JPG) [Zoravor Surp Astvatsatsin Church](/wiki/Zoravor_Surp_Astvatsatsin_Church "Zoravor Surp Astvatsatsin Church")

Many of the structures of Yerevan had been destroyed either during foreign invasions or as a result of the devastating [earthquake in 1679](/wiki/1679_Armenia_earthquake "1679 Armenia earthquake"). However, some structures have remained moderately intact and were renovated during the following years.

[Erebuni Fortress](/wiki/Erebuni_Fortress "Erebuni Fortress"), also known as *Arin Berd* , is the hill where the city of Yerevan was founded in 782 BC by King [Argishti I](/wiki/Argishti_I_of_Urartu "Argishti I of Urartu"). The remains of other structures from earlier periods are also found in Shengavit.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/2014_Erywa%C5%84%2C_B%C5%82%C4%99kitny_Meczet_%2809%29.jpg/220px-2014_Erywa%C5%84%2C_B%C5%82%C4%99kitny_Meczet_%2809%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2014_Erywa%C5%84,_B%C5%82%C4%99kitny_Meczet_(09).jpg) The Blue Mosque

The 4th-century chapel of the Holy Mother of God and the 6th-century [Tsiranavor Church](/wiki/Katoghike_Tsiranavor_Church_of_Avan "Katoghike Tsiranavor Church of Avan") both located in [Avan District](/wiki/Avan_District "Avan District") at the north of Yerevan, are among the oldest surviving Christian structures of the city. Originally a suburb at the north of Yerevan, Avan was eventually absorbed by the city's gradual expansion. The district is also home to the remains of Surp Hovhannes Chapel dating back to the 12--13th centuries.

[Katoghike Church](/wiki/Katoghike_Church,_Yerevan "Katoghike Church, Yerevan"); a medieval chapel (a section of once much larger basilica) in the centre of Yerevan, built in 1264, is one of the best preserved churches of the city.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-170)^ [Zoravor Surp Astvatsatsin Church](/wiki/Zoravor_Surp_Astvatsatsin_Church "Zoravor Surp Astvatsatsin Church") is also among the best surviving churches of Yerevan, built 1693--94 right after the devastating earthquake, on the ruins of a medieval church. [Saint Sarkis Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Sarkis_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Sarkis Cathedral, Yerevan") rebuilt in 1835--42, is the seat of [Araratian Pontifical Diocese](/wiki/Araratian_Pontifical_Diocese "Araratian Pontifical Diocese") of the [Armenian Apostolic Church](/wiki/Armenian_Apostolic_Church "Armenian Apostolic Church").{#cite_ref-170}

The [Blue Mosque](/wiki/Blue_Mosque,_Yerevan "Blue Mosque, Yerevan") or "Gök Jami", built between 1764 and 1768 at the centre of the city, is currently the only operating mosque in Armenia.

The [Red Bridge](/wiki/Red_Bridge_(Yerevan) "Red Bridge (Yerevan)") of [Hrazdan River](/wiki/Hrazdan_River "Hrazdan River") is a 17th-century structure, built after the 1679 earthquake and later reconstructed in 1830.  

#### Contemporary {#Contemporary}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D5%91%D5%A5%D5%B2%D5%A1%D5%BD%D5%BA%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%A9%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A3%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B6.JPG/220px-%D5%91%D5%A5%D5%B2%D5%A1%D5%BD%D5%BA%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%A9%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A3%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B6.JPG)](/wiki/File:%D5%91%D5%A5%D5%B2%D5%A1%D5%BD%D5%BA%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%A1%D5%B6_%D5%A9%D5%A1%D5%B6%D5%A3%D5%A1%D6%80%D5%A1%D5%B6.JPG) Aerial view of Tsitsernakaberd memorial and the [genocide](/wiki/Armenian_genocide "Armenian genocide") museum

[Yerevan Opera Theater](/wiki/Yerevan_Opera_Theater "Yerevan Opera Theater") or the Armenian National Academic Opera and Ballet Theatre opened in 1933, is a major landmark in the city along with the [Mesrop Mashtots Matenadaran](/wiki/Matenadaran "Matenadaran") opened in 1959, and [Tsitsernakaberd](/wiki/Tsitsernakaberd "Tsitsernakaberd") monument of the [Armenian genocide](/wiki/Armenian_genocide "Armenian genocide") opened in 1967.

[Moscow Cinema](/wiki/Moscow_Cinema "Moscow Cinema"), opened in 1937 on the site of [Saint Paul and Peter Church](/wiki/Saint_Paul_and_Peter_Church,_Yerevan "Saint Paul and Peter Church, Yerevan") of the 5th century, is an important example of the Soviet-era architecture. In 1959, a monument was erected near the Yerevan Railway Station dedicated to the legendary Armenian hero [David of Sassoun](/wiki/David_of_Sassoun "David of Sassoun"). The monumental statue of [Mother Armenia](/wiki/Mother_Armenia "Mother Armenia") is a female personification of the Armenian nation, erected in 1967, replacing the huge statue of [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin") in the [Victory park](/wiki/Victory_Park,_Yerevan "Victory Park, Yerevan").

[Komitas Pantheon](/wiki/Komitas_Pantheon "Komitas Pantheon") is a cemetery opened in 1936 where many famous Armenians are buried, while the [Yerablur](/wiki/Yerablur "Yerablur") Pantheon, is a military cemetery where over 1,000 Armenian martyrs of the [Nagorno-Karabakh conflict](/wiki/Nagorno-Karabakh_conflict "Nagorno-Karabakh conflict") are buried since 1990.

Many new notable buildings were constructed after the independence of Armenia such as the [Yerevan Cascade](/wiki/Yerevan_Cascade "Yerevan Cascade"), and the [Saint Gregory Cathedral](/wiki/Saint_Gregory_the_Illuminator_Cathedral,_Yerevan "Saint Gregory the Illuminator Cathedral, Yerevan") opened in 2001 to commemorate the 1700th anniversary of Christianity in Armenia. In May 2016, a monumental statue of the prominent Armenian statesman and military leader [Garegin Nzhdeh](/wiki/Garegin_Nzhdeh "Garegin Nzhdeh") was erected at the centre of Yerevan.  

Transportation {#Transportation}
--------------------------------

### Air {#Air}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Zvartnots_airport.jpg/220px-Zvartnots_airport.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zvartnots_airport.jpg) The main entrance to the [Zvartnots Airport](/wiki/Zvartnots_Airport "Zvartnots Airport")

Yerevan is served by the [Zvartnots International Airport](/wiki/Zvartnots_International_Airport "Zvartnots International Airport"), located 12 kilometres (7 miles) west of the city center.

A second airport, [Erebuni Airport](/wiki/Erebuni_Airport "Erebuni Airport"), is located just south of the city. Since the independence, "Erebuni" is mainly used for military or private flights. The [Armenian Air Force](/wiki/Armenian_Air_Force "Armenian Air Force") has equally installed its base there and there are several [MiG-29s](/wiki/MiG-29 "MiG-29") stationed on Erebuni's tarmac.  

### City buses, public vans and trolleybuses {#City_buses.2C_public_vans_and_trolleybuses}

|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png) | This section needs to be **updated** . Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information. *(May 2024)* |

Main article: [Trolleybuses in Yerevan](/wiki/Trolleybuses_in_Yerevan "Trolleybuses in Yerevan")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/2014_Erywa%C5%84%2C_Marszrutka_w_centrum_stolicy_%2801%29.jpg/220px-2014_Erywa%C5%84%2C_Marszrutka_w_centrum_stolicy_%2801%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2014_Erywa%C5%84,_Marszrutka_w_centrum_stolicy_(01).jpg) A [marshrutka](/wiki/Marshrutka "Marshrutka")

Public transport in Yerevan is heavily privatized and mostly handled by around 60 private operators. As of May 2017, 39 city bus lines are being operated throughout Yerevan.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-171)^ These lines mostly consist of about 425 [Bogdan](/wiki/Bogdan_(bus_company) "Bogdan (bus company)"), [Higer City Bus](/wiki/Higer_Bus "Higer Bus") and [Hyundai County](/wiki/Hyundai_County "Hyundai County") buses. However, the market share these buses in public transit is only about 39.1%.{#cite_ref-171}

But the 50.4% of public transit is still served by "public vans", locally known as [marshrutka](/wiki/Marshrutka "Marshrutka"). These are about 1210 Russian-made [GAZelle](/wiki/GAZelle "GAZelle") vans with 13 seats, that operate same way as buses, having 79 different lines with certain routes and same stops. According to Yerevan Municipality office, in future, marshrutkas should be replaced by ordinary larger buses. Despite having about 13 seats, the limit of passengers is not controlled, so usually these vans carry many more people who stand inside.

The [Yerevan trolleybus system](/wiki/Trolleybuses_in_Yerevan "Trolleybuses in Yerevan") has been operating since 1949. Some old Soviet-era trolleybuses have been replaced with comparably new ones. As of May 2017, only 5 trolleybus lines are in operation (2.6% share), with around 45 units in service. The trolleybus system is owned and operated by the municipality.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Yerevan_trolleybus_view.jpg/220px-Yerevan_trolleybus_view.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yerevan_trolleybus_view.jpg) A trolleybus in Yerevan

The tram network that operated in Yerevan since 1906 was decommissioned in January 2004. Its operation had a cost 2.4 times higher than the generated profits, which pushed the municipality to shut down the network,^[\[167\]](#cite_note-172)^ despite a last-ditch effort to save it towards the end of 2003. Since the closure, the rails have been dismantled and sold.{#cite_ref-172}

Due to being dispersed among dozens of private operators, the transportation is barely regulated, with only trip fee is being a subject of regulation. Thus, the quality of vehicles is often inadequate, with no certain regulations for safety. Unlike the majority of world capitals, there is no established ticketing system in Yerevan's public transportation. Passengers need to pay the money directly to the driver when getting out of the vehicle. The fare -being one of the few things that is regulated- is fixed and controlled by authorities.

The central station in Nor Kilikia neighbourhood serves as bus terminal for inter-city transport, serving outbound routes towards practically all the cities of Armenia as well as abroad, notably [Tbilisi](/wiki/Tbilisi "Tbilisi") and [Tabriz](/wiki/Tabriz "Tabriz").  

### Underground {#Underground}

Main article: [Yerevan Metro](/wiki/Yerevan_Metro "Yerevan Metro")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Metro_Yerevan_Republic_Square_metro_station.jpg/220px-Metro_Yerevan_Republic_Square_metro_station.jpg)](/wiki/File:Metro_Yerevan_Republic_Square_metro_station.jpg) The [Republic Square underground station](/wiki/Republic_Square_(metro_station) "Republic Square (metro station)")

The [Yerevan Metro](/wiki/Yerevan_Metro "Yerevan Metro") named after Karen Demirchyan, ([Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_language "Armenian language"): Կարեն Դեմիրճյանի անվան Երեւանի մետրոպոլիտեն կայարան (*Karen Dyemirchyani anvan Yerevani metropoliten kayaran* )) is a [rapid transit](/wiki/Rapid_transit "Rapid transit") system that serves the capital city since 1981. It has a single line of 12.1 km (7.5 mi) length with 10 active stations and 45 units in service. The interiors of the stations resemble that of the former western Soviet nations, with [chandeliers](/wiki/Chandelier "Chandelier") hanging from the corridors. The metro stations had most of their names changed after the collapse of the Soviet Union and the independence of the Republic of Armenia.

A northeastern extension of the line with two new stations is currently being developed. The construction of the first station (*Ajapnyak* ) and of the one-kilometre (0.62-mile) tunnel linking it to the rest of the network will cost US$18 million.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-173)^ The time of the end of the project has not yet been defined. Another long-term project is the construction of two new lines, but these have been suspended due to lack of finance.{#cite_ref-173}

The system transports more than 60,000 people on a daily basis.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^  

### Railway {#Railway}

Main article: [Armenian Railway](/wiki/Armenian_Railway "Armenian Railway")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/David_of_Sasun_Yerevan.jpg/220px-David_of_Sasun_Yerevan.jpg)](/wiki/File:David_of_Sasun_Yerevan.jpg) Yerevan railway station, with the [statue](/wiki/Sasuntsi_Davit_(statue) "Sasuntsi Davit (statue)") of [David of Sassoun](/wiki/David_of_Sassoun "David of Sassoun")

Yerevan has a single central railway station (several railway stations of suburbs have not been used since 1990) that is connected to the metro via the *Sasuntsi Davit* station. The railway station is made in Soviet-style architecture with its long point on the building roof, representing the symbols of communism: [red star](/wiki/Red_star "Red star"), [hammer and sickle](/wiki/Hammer_and_sickle "Hammer and sickle"). Due to the Turkish and Azerbaijani blockades of Armenia, there is only one international train that passes by once every two days, with neighboring Georgia being its destination. For a sum of 9 000 to 18 000 [dram](/wiki/Armenian_dram "Armenian dram"), it is possible to take the night train to the Georgian capital, Tbilisi.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-174)^ This train then continues to its destination of [Batumi](/wiki/Batumi "Batumi"), on the shores of the [Black sea](/wiki/Black_sea "Black sea") in the summer season.{#cite_ref-174}

The only railway that goes to Iran to the south passes by the closed border of [Nakhchivan](/wiki/Nakhchivan_Autonomous_Republic "Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic"). For this reason, there are no trains that go south from Yerevan.

During the first decade of the 21st century, the South Caucasus Railway CJSC --- which is the current operator of the railway system in Armenia---announced its readiness to put the Yerevan-Gyumri-Kars railway line in service in case the Armenian-Turkish protocols are ratified and the opening of the borders between the two countries is achieved.

As of July 2017, the following railway trips are scheduled from and to Yerevan:

* Yerevan-Tbilisi-Batumi-Yerevan, with a daily trip operating since 15 June 2017, in coordination with the [Georgian Railways](/wiki/Georgian_Railways "Georgian Railways").^[\[170\]](#cite_note-175)^{#cite_ref-175}
* Yerevan-Gyumri-Yerevan, with 3 daily trips operating since 15 June 2017.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-176)^{#cite_ref-176}
* Yerevan-Yeraskh-Yerevan, with a daily trip operating since 12 July 2014.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-177)^{#cite_ref-177}
* Yerevan-Araks-Yerevan, with a daily trip.^[\[173\]](#cite_note-178)^{#cite_ref-178}
* Yerevan-Shorzha-Yerevan, with weekend trips.

The Yerevan-Ararat-Yerevan route is temporarily not in operation, while the Yerevan-Tbilisi-Yerevan route will operate starting from 2 October 2017.  

### Taxi {#Taxi}

Yerevan prides itself on having connections 24/7 as taxis are available at any time of the day or night.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-179)^ Taxicab service companies cover the entire city in addition to many online taxi service providers, including GG Taxi, Utaxi and [Yandex.Taxi](/wiki/Yandex.Taxi "Yandex.Taxi").{#cite_ref-179}  

Economy and services {#Economy_and_services}
--------------------------------------------

### Industry {#Industry}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Building_in_the_center_of_Yerevan.jpg/220px-Building_in_the_center_of_Yerevan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Building_in_the_center_of_Yerevan.jpg) Yerevan Ararat Brandy Factory

As of 2013^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Yerevan&action=edit)^, the share of Yerevan in the annual total industrial product of Armenia is 41%.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-180)^ The industry of Yerevan is quite diversified including chemicals, primary metals and steel products, [machinery](/wiki/Machinery "Machinery"), rubber products, plastics, rugs and carpets, textiles, clothing and footwear, jewellery, wood products and furniture, building materials and stone-processing, alcoholic beverages, mineral water, dairy product and processed food. Even though the economic crisis of the '90s ravaged the industry of the country, several factories remain always in service, notably in the petrochemical and the aluminium sectors.{#cite_ref-180}

Armenian beverages, especially Armenian [cognac](/wiki/Cognac_(drink) "Cognac (drink)") and beer, have a worldwide fame. Hence, Yerevan is home to many leading enterprises of Armenia and the [Caucasus](/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus") for the production of alcoholic beverages, such as the [Yerevan Ararat Brandy Factory](/wiki/Yerevan_Ararat_Brandy_Factory "Yerevan Ararat Brandy Factory"), [Yerevan Brandy Company](/wiki/Yerevan_Brandy_Company "Yerevan Brandy Company"), [Yerevan Champagne Wines Factory](/wiki/Yerevan_Champagne_Wines_Factory "Yerevan Champagne Wines Factory"), "Beer of Yerevan" (Kilikia Beer) brewery, Armco Brandy Factory, [Proshyan Brandy Factory](/wiki/Proshyan_Brandy_Factory "Proshyan Brandy Factory") and Astafian Wine-Brandy Factory. The 2 tobacco producers in Yerevan are the "Cigaronne" and "Grand Tabak" companies.
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/ArmChamapgne.jpg/220px-ArmChamapgne.jpg)](/wiki/File:ArmChamapgne.jpg) Yerevan Champagne Wines Factory

[Carpet industry in Armenia](/wiki/Armenian_carpet "Armenian carpet") has a deeply rooted history with ancient traditions, therefore, carpet production is rather developed in Yerevan with three major factories that also produce hand-made rugs.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-181)^^[\[177\]](#cite_note-182)^^[\[178\]](#cite_note-183)^ The "Megerian Carpet" factory is the leading in this sector.{#cite_ref-183}

Other major plants in the city include the "Nairit" chemical and rubber plant, [Rusal Armenal](/wiki/Rusal_Armenal "Rusal Armenal") aluminum foil mill, "Grand Candy" Armenian-Canadian confectionery manufacturers, "Arcolad" chocolate factory, "Marianna" factory for dairy products, "Talgrig Group" for wheat and flour products, "Shant" ice cream factory, "Crown Chemicals" for paints, "ATMC" travertine mining company, Yerevan Watch Factory "AWI watches", Yerevan Jewellery Plant, and the mineral water factories of "Arzni", "Sil", and "Dilijan Frolova".

Food products include processed meat, all types of canneries, wheat and flour, sweets and chocolate, dried fruits, soft drinks and beverages. Building materials mainly include travertine, crushed stones, asphalt and asphalt concrete.  

### Finance and banking {#Finance_and_banking}

|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Americas.svg.png) | This article needs to be **updated** . Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information. *(June 2020)* |

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/CBA_building.JPG/220px-CBA_building.JPG)](/wiki/File:CBA_building.JPG) The Central Bank of Armenia [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Elite_Plaza_Business_Center_Main.jpg/220px-Elite_Plaza_Business_Center_Main.jpg)](/wiki/File:Elite_Plaza_Business_Center_Main.jpg) The [Elite Plaza Business Center](/wiki/Elite_Plaza_Business_Center "Elite Plaza Business Center")

As an attractive outsourcing location for Western European, Russian and American multinationals, Yerevan headquarters many international companies. It is Armenia's financial hub, being home to the [Central Bank of Armenia](/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Armenia "Central Bank of Armenia"), the [Armenian Stock Exchange](/wiki/Armenian_Stock_Exchange "Armenian Stock Exchange") (NASDAQ OMX Armenia), as well as the majority of the country's largest commercial banks.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-184)^ As of 2013^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Yerevan&action=edit)^, the city dominates over 85% of the annual total services in Armenia, as well as over 84% of the annual total retail trade.{#cite_ref-184}

Many subsidiaries of [Russian](/wiki/Russia "Russia") service companies and banks operate in Yerevan, including [Gazprom](/wiki/Gazprom_Armenia "Gazprom Armenia"), [Ingo Armenia](/wiki/Ingo_Armenia "Ingo Armenia"), [Rosgosstrakh](/wiki/Rosgosstrakh "Rosgosstrakh") and [VTB Bank](/wiki/VTB_Bank "VTB Bank"). The [ACBA-Credit Agricole](/wiki/ACBA-Credit_Agricole_Bank "ACBA-Credit Agricole Bank") is a subsidiary of the French [Crédit Agricole](/wiki/Cr%C3%A9dit_Agricole "Crédit Agricole"), while the [HSBC](/wiki/HSBC "HSBC") Bank Armenia is also operating in Yerevan.  

### Construction {#Construction}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Pavstos_Buzand_street_2015%2C_Yerevan_%281%29.jpg/220px-Pavstos_Buzand_street_2015%2C_Yerevan_%281%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pavstos_Buzand_street_2015,_Yerevan_(1).jpg) A 19th-century building in downtown Yerevan, remodeled with modern additions [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Cafesjian_Center_for_the_Arts_%28CCA_1%29.jpg/220px-Cafesjian_Center_for_the_Arts_%28CCA_1%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cafesjian_Center_for_the_Arts_(CCA_1).jpg) [Cascade](/wiki/Yerevan_Cascade "Yerevan Cascade") complex

The construction sector has experienced a significant growth during the 1st decade of the 21st century.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-185)^ Starting from 2000, Yerevan has witnessed a massive construction boom, funded mostly by Armenian millionaires from Russia and the United States, with an extensive and controversial redevelopment process in which many 18th and 19th-century buildings have been demolished and replaced with new buildings. This growth was coupled with a significant increase in real estate prices.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Pavstos_Byuzand_street.jpg/220px-Pavstos_Byuzand_street.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pavstos_Byuzand_street.jpg) Historical districts being demolished and replaced with modern buildings

Many major construction projects has been conducted in Yerevan, such as the [Northern Avenue](/wiki/Northern_Avenue_(Yerevan) "Northern Avenue (Yerevan)") and the rehabilitation of *Old Yerevan* on [Aram Street](/wiki/Aram_Street "Aram Street"). The Northern Avenue is completed and was opened in 2007, while the *Old Yerevan* project is still under development.
